commit_message:
Handle --flagfile by converting to .ini style

Add code to translate flagfiles into .ini config files so that we can
deprecate and, eventually remove, --flagfile.

By using the flagfile compat code, we no longer need to process the
contents of flagfiles as CLI options and we can reduce the number
of CLI options to a sane set:

  --verbose
  --logdir
  --logfile
  --use_syslog
  --use_stderr
  --connection_type
  --sql_connection
  --api_paste_config
  --state_path
  --lock_path
  --fake_network
  --fake_rabbit

This, in turn, means we can remove the evil hacks which we needed in
order to register CLI options after the initial parsing of the command
line.

Change-Id: I9e24008fa634d7c8378b253c1f7a6d2169076086

commit_message:
Backslash continuations (misc.)

Fixes bug #925166

This patch for packages which have few backslash continuations.

Follow up patches will be for packages network, scheduler, virt,
db/sqlalchemy, tests, and api/openstack.

Change-Id: I4200010b47b33fa8b9115b5d379b543200f6668d

 * Fix spaceypoo

subject: optimize libvirt image cache usage
messages:
[{'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-02-02 01:31:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This is Vish's suggested follow up to:
https://review.openstack.org/#change,3627"}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-02-02 02:21:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-02 07:24:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

looks good overall.  Couple of comments and questions inline.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-02-02 10:23:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (4 inline comments)

responses...'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-02-02 12:47:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-02-02 12:49:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

OK I defaulted size back to None,
got rid of the _sm suffix.
Also I adjusted the way _cache_image() was called in pre_block_migration().
I've a separate patch for pre_block_migration() as I
don't think it's doing the right thing currently."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-02-02 22:52:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-02-03 11:30:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Given that review 2902 has landed I'd like to hold off on this untill I consider the consequences.  I'm guessing I might need to adjust that code now also. I'm travelling until Feb 7th"}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-02-04 09:42:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Looking at this, I don't think its too bad to tweak the cache code to work with this scheme. The hardest bit will be deciding what images from glance to keep now that they're not in the chain of use. I think we can work something reasonable out though."}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-02-09 11:29:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

Michael has kindly adjusted the cache cleanup for this new scheme (in https://review.openstack.org/#change,3795).

I've also rebased and addressed Michaels correct observation

commit_message:
optimize libvirt image cache usage

When dealing with cow images, minimize the number of downloads,
by caching both the original download and a resized derivative,
with extra disk space being used for the downloaded image.
This part was suggested by Vish Ishaya.

When dealing with raw images, don't bother caching the resized
derivative, as it's quicker to just copy the downloaded image
to the instance dir and resize in place.  Similarly when
generating a raw image, do so directly to the instance dir.

Change-Id: I1458b2c39a51d7d9f5bdfff53155431c863b8a40

of log entries that aren't internationalized

commit_message:
Split functions to avoid eventlet import.

Some of these functions are used in setup.py. In a virtualenv
based workflow, python setup.py sdist is called to create a
tarball which is then installed into the virtualenv. These
functions need to be in a separate file so that they can be
imported by setup.py without eventlet needing to be installed.

Change-Id: I6f7dc9614895b8c91135c62373b98afe55e1fc7d

commit_message:
Auto-updating for data in data tables!

This adds a few layers of functionality:

  * Support for preemptive actions that run before data
    is loaded into the table (saving on API calls).
  * "Update" actions that fetch new data for specific rows.
  * Automatic AJAX polling for rows which are in an "unknown" state.

The table/action changes were accomplished without breaking any existing tests.
Also includes unit tests to verify the new behavior.
Lastly, includes a big chunk of new docs to begin flashing out topic guides
and examples for working with Horizon beyond just an API reference.

Change-Id: Ifd15919066825d7269bbe4efcb4d51b8ed19baed

messages:
[{'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-10-08 18:51:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Quick question and a comment:

1) Can you provide more feedback as to why/how this bug might be encountered in the wild? The API specification (docs.openstack.org) doesn't specify a GET on /limits/<id>, only on /limits. In my opinion that would make it, in my mind, so the GET on /limits/<id> would return a 404 instead of a 501. If a method isn't there, most likely it's because it's not defined in the API and thus should just 404.

2) While not trying to split hairs, the tests provided are on the right track to being unit tests, but they still interact with the WSGI layer (in my mind this makes them integration tests as it is testing the integration of 2 or more components).

Directly invoking the controller with a constructed Request would, I believe, simplify the test and provide the same information. For example, the test would go from:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/2658/

to (un-tested)

http://paste.openstack.org/show/2657/

That being said, testing the integration between the WSGI/controller layers is important, but I'm attempting to push testing simpler and simpler situations for the future."}, {'account_id': 1775, 'date': '2011-10-18 13:42:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Brian,

Thanks for the review. Inline response:

>1) Can you provide more feedback as to why/how this bug >might be encountered in the wild? The API specification >(docs.openstack.org) doesn't specify a GET on /limits>>/<id>, only on /limits. In my opinion that would make it, >in my mind, so the GET on /limits/<id> would return a 404 >instead of a 501. If a method isn't there, most likely >it's because it's not defined in the API and thus should >just 404.


This bug will be encountered always because the routing middleware generates the following mappings of limit controller:

                                  POST    /limits.:(format)                                
                                  POST    /limits                                          
formatted_limits                  GET     /limits.:(format)                                
limits                            GET     /limits                                          
formatted_new_limit               GET     /limits/new.:(format)                            
new_limit                         GET     /limits/new                                      
                                  PUT     /limits/:(id).:(format)                          
                                  PUT     /limits/:(id)                                    
                                  DELETE  /limits/:(id).:(format)                          
                                  DELETE  /limits/:(id)                                    
formatted_edit_limit              GET     /limits/:(id)/edit.:(format)                     
edit_limit                        GET     /limits/:(id)/edit                               
formatted_limit                   GET     /limits/:(id).:(format)                          
limit                             GET     /limits/:(id)  


So when these mapping resolved to show, create etc methods then controller class just throws an attribute exception because those methods have not been defined in controller class. You can verify this through:

curl -i  -H 'X-Auth-Token: 6b48b125a309712feff548cc9211222e3848c68f'  "http://localhost:8774/v1.0/limits" -X POST

The above will throw an exception:
{"cloudServersFault": {"message": "'LimitsControllerV10' object has no attribute 'create'", "code": 500}} 


2) While not trying to split hairs, the tests provided are on the right track to being unit tests, but they still interact with the WSGI layer (in my mind this makes them integration tests as it is testing the integration of 2 or more components).

Absolutely agree with you. I will make this change.

Thanks.

--Ahmad'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-10-18 14:03:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Awesome, thanks for the detailed explanation! It's much appreciated."}, {'account_id': 335, 'date': '2011-10-19 23:05:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2011-10-21 20:38:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

Just waiting on the test fixes per what blamar suggested.  Looks good, otherwise.'}, {'account_id': 1775, 'date': '2011-11-10 15:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1775, 'date': '2011-11-10 15:14:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Simplified unit tests as per Brian's suggestions."}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-11-10 15:41:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Very nice, thank you!'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-11-21 19:26:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm seeing some unit tests failures with this branch:

Full set of failures is here:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/3474/"}, {'account_id': 1775, 'date': '2011-11-22 10:15:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Very odd. I will look into this. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 1775, 'date': '2012-01-03 17:34:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1775, 'date': '2012-01-03 17:37:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi,

I have submitted the patch 3 but I just rebased it on top of master. Patch 2 also passes all the unit test and patch 3 also passes all the unit tests related to limit controller interface.

I do not see any failures when I run the test suite. The logs of smokestack shows the following:

ERROR: test_limit_update (nova.tests.api.openstack.v2.test_limits.LimitsControllerTest)

I don't see v2 directory in my source code. I wonder if that is the cause of problem.

--Ahmad"}, {'account_id': 1775, 'date': '2012-01-04 09:33:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1775, 'date': '2012-01-04 09:35:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Ahhh, the issue was that the code base has been diverted in trunk. Fixed the problem and unit tests pass now.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-01-04 19:57:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary use of LoopingCall in nova/virt/xenapi/vm_utils.py

The code synchronously blocks waiting on the LoopingCall to finish
anyway and the use of a maximum of number of attempts ends up being
awkwardly fit in.

Also, remove an out-of-date comment about future use of LoopingCall

Change-Id: Ife397e171f28fff5e73c70e6957cecdd09a42d68

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-02-08 22:41:03.000000000', 'message': 'Stop using LoopingCall in nova.virt.xenapi_conn:wait_for_task()

The use of utils.LoopingCall is unnecessary since code waits immediately
for the LoopingCall to finish. This results in code that is more
complicated than necessary, but also it creates an extra greenthread
that ends up obfuscating stack trace in case of exceptions.

Change-Id: Iaf0909a4f2307e8657e7baa15cb5a7852ba6feca
'}]
commit_message:
Stop using LoopingCall in nova.virt.xenapi_conn:wait_for_task()

The use of utils.LoopingCall is unnecessary since code waits immediately
for the LoopingCall to finish. This results in code that is more
complicated than necessary, but also it creates an extra greenthread
that ends up obfuscating stack trace in case of exceptions.

Change-Id: Iaf0909a4f2307e8657e7baa15cb5a7852ba6feca

[{'created': '2012-02-08 22:08:32.000000000', 'message': 'Consistently update instance in nova/compute/manager.py

The code used a mix of self.db.instance_update and self._update_instance,
so settle on self._update_instance. Also, the code used a mix of
self._update_instance and self._set_instance_error_state, so settle on
self._set_instance_error_state. This also changes the code to not clear
task_state in all cases, leaving it set for debugging purposes.

Change-Id: I5c841ebfb60ba4acf62382060e416ea780bd66ba
'}]
commit_message:
Consistently update instance in nova/compute/manager.py

The code used a mix of self.db.instance_update and self._update_instance,
so settle on self._update_instance. Also, the code used a mix of
self._update_instance and self._set_instance_error_state, so settle on
self._set_instance_error_state. This also changes the code to not clear
task_state in all cases, leaving it set for debugging purposes.

Change-Id: I5c841ebfb60ba4acf62382060e416ea780bd66ba

For example, the following nova.conf configuration file:

--osapi_compute_extension=nova.api.openstack.compute.contrib.select_extensions
--osapi_compute_ext_list=Createserverext,Extended_status

Would load only the Createserverext and Extended_status extensions.

Change-Id: I8c2a444683c6e4114875827b44ef01e457eb94ac
'}]
commit_message:
Added ability to load specific extensions.

For example, the following nova.conf configuration file:

--osapi_compute_extension=nova.api.openstack.compute.contrib.select_extensions
--osapi_compute_ext_list=Createserverext,Extended_status

Would load only the Createserverext and Extended_status extensions.

Change-Id: I8c2a444683c6e4114875827b44ef01e457eb94ac

If the password has a unicode character in it, bcrypt breaks.  So encode it using utf-8.  utf-8 should mean that existing hashes still work.

Change-Id: I4f9f3b636c8728234ada87de62d22bed2ff8eb60
'}, {'created': '2012-02-08 21:19:33.000000000', 'message': 'Cope with unicode passwords or None

If the password has a unicode character in it, bcrypt breaks.  So encode it using utf-8.  utf-8 should mean that existing hashes still work.

Change-Id: I4f9f3b636c8728234ada87de62d22bed2ff8eb60
'}]
commit_message:
Cope with unicode passwords or None

If the password has a unicode character in it, bcrypt breaks.  So encode it using utf-8.  utf-8 should mean that existing hashes still work.

Change-Id: I4f9f3b636c8728234ada87de62d22bed2ff8eb60

commit_message:
pep8 should be applied to the unit tests also.

However, many of the unit tests require some pretty big tweaks.
For now, mark each such file with 'PLEASE_PEP8_FIX_ME'; they will be
skipped from pep8 validation, but there's still a marker that this
needs fixing.

Change-Id: I7366b21a21d8dcd650c4bd2bec48e9dafd1f581e

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-02-08 19:30:57.000000000', 'message': 'Handle service failures during finish_resize gracefully

Fixes bug 928474

If exceptions occur in the network or image service during finish_resize(),
the instance can be left in RESIZE state. This change will ensure those
exceptions will move the instance to ERROR as well.

Change-Id: I638db27da27310ccd55d52453c3aadaa41634040
'}]
commit_message:
Handle service failures during finish_resize gracefully

Fixes bug 928474

If exceptions occur in the network or image service during finish_resize(),
the instance can be left in RESIZE state. This change will ensure those
exceptions will move the instance to ERROR as well.

Change-Id: I638db27da27310ccd55d52453c3aadaa41634040

commit_message:
Allows test_virt_drivers to work when run alone

 * Properly sets fake_resize using a stub in test_libvirt
 * Adds a stub for test_virt_drivers
 * Fixes typo and misuse of flags in setUp and TearDown
 * Fixes bug 925891

Change-Id: I015e942305f6a08941168ca0ccadb2382db064d7

 * changes call for create_snapshot from contrib/volumes.py

commit_message:
Fixes volume snapshotting issues and tests

 * changes call for create_snapshot from contrib/volumes.py
 * fixes some raises in volume/snaphsots.py
 * rewrites volume api tests to use the right endpoint
 * updates contrib snapshots test to catch the error
 * fixes bug 928567
 * fixes bug 928588

Change-Id: Ifa6bd8b70dc0df5c8811b0123072ba83eb170a45

subject: Fix bug 921814 changes handling of adminPass in API.
messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-04 00:42:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Discussing this with Brian Waldon, we feel that actually returning None instead of a string is preferrable. We are going to attempt to update the spec to say that it can return a string or NULL

Also a few whitespace changes."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-04 01:34:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Actually, the adminPass attribute is already defined as optional in the xsd. So the preferred path forward here is to just not set an adminPass attribute if enable_instance_password is False.'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-02-04 02:14:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-02-04 02:18:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

I've added some additional comments that may be worth addressing."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-02-04 02:19:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

"}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-02-04 02:21:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

patch set 2 changes the return to None.

Brian,  what's the risk of breaking clients if we don't return the attribute?  it might be optional in the schema, but the docs indicate it's always being returned, so there might be code outside unit tests which expects it."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-02-04 02:22:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Applied my p1 comments to p2.'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-02-04 02:37:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

maru makes two good points:

1) Is there a policy in place for constants like my PW_IGNORED, or sohuld I just set one up (nova/constatns.py ?)

2) Do we want to make sure the tests get run for both variations of the flag ?'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-02-04 05:11:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-02-04 05:14:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Fix bug 921814 changes handling of adminPass in API.

Add a new nova configuration flag, boolean, enable_instance_password.

When the flag is True (default), existing behavior is unchanged.

When the flag is False, responses from the create or
rebuild API calls don't include the adminPass attribute.

Change-Id: Icb2bd703770f3a39bb1e458dc31e1489d48da7c1

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-02-06 17:43:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I generally don't like forking from threads because of potential deadlock issues... since only the thread that called fork() will exist in a child and a different thread in the parent could have been holding a lock that has no chance of being released in a child.  I'd have to understand python internals to know if that could actually happen here, though.  The comment on using os._exit() suggests working around some weird behavior, though.

Threads really aren't needed for this.  What one could do is have do_start() fork all of the children initially by calling launch() on them all.  Then... afterwards have a single loop doing waitpid()s looking for *any* children that have died and re-fork them.

But... that essentially means re-writing this whole patch ;)  and I'm not sure I'm going to go as far as requiring that.  I'll wait for comment back first..  maybe there's something I'm missing with the use of threads here."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-02-07 16:55:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Hi Chris,

Thanks for the feedback.

The reason for the os._exit() call is that sys.exit() simply raises an exception which is caught on a non-main thread.

Now, I'm not sure if the unreleased lock issue is a realistic possibility in this case. If it is, I could look at restructuring the code to avoid the forks from non-main threads.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-02-08 09:43:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-02-08 09:44:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Hi Chris,

I've restructured the code in patch set 7 to avoid the forks from a non-main thread that you were concerned about.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-02-08 16:32:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(2 inline comments)

Continuing the battle against the unnecessary backslash…

(To be clear, I won't hold up your patch just for use of backslashes; but if you need to resubmit, I'd appreciate it if you could do something about them.)"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-02-08 16:33:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Respawn glance services on unexpected death.

Fixes bug 923894

Add new '--respawn' option to cause glance services launched via
glance-control to be monitored for unexpected death and resuscitated
as necessary.

This option will cause glance-control itself to remain running.

Deliberately stopped services are not respawned, neither are rapidly
bouncing services (where process death occurred within one second
of the last launch).

Change-Id: I1a9a99cce9b6ad43274836e39ebe4f29c19455af

[{'created': '2012-02-07 18:48:51.000000000', 'message': 'Use sendfile() for zero-copy of uploaded images.

Avoid needless client-side copying through userspace of uploaded
image file content, using pysendfile to wrap the sendfile() system
call instead of reading the file one chunk at a time.

The existing iterator pattern is maintained for consistency and
to allow send progress to be followed by wrapping the iteration.

The performance gain only applies to the client-->glance API service
leg, so whether the overall speed-up is noticeable depends on the
image store in use. For example, it would be impreceptible with a
storage backend showing relatively high PUT latency, such as S3,
as the blocking Store.add() call would dominate.

At the other extreme, uploading large images via the loopback to
file-based store is about 60% faster. Detailed performance figures
for more realistic scenarios to follow when hardware is available
for benchmarking.

Change-Id: Ia8c74e76d3d6c63e9a9b38ab455a4e6edb47fba9
'}, {'created': '2012-02-08 09:40:35.000000000', 'message': 'Use sendfile() for zero-copy of uploaded images.

commit_message:
Use sendfile() for zero-copy of uploaded images.

Implements bp support-sendfile

Avoid needless client-side copying through userspace of uploaded
image file content, using pysendfile to wrap the sendfile() system
call instead of reading the file one chunk at a time.

The existing iterator pattern is maintained for consistency and
to allow send progress to be followed by wrapping the iteration.

The performance gain only applies to the client-->glance API service
leg, so whether the overall speed-up is noticeable depends on the
image store in use. For example, it would be imperceptible with a
storage backend showing relatively high PUT latency, such as S3,
as the blocking Store.add() call would dominate.

At the other extreme, uploading large images via the loopback to
file-based store is about 60% faster. Detailed performance figures
for more realistic scenarios to follow when hardware is available
for benchmarking.

Change-Id: Ia8c74e76d3d6c63e9a9b38ab455a4e6edb47fba9

commit_message:
Ensures duplicate users and tenants can't be made

 * adds test for duplicate names and ids for backends
 * also adds test for rename duplicates and changing ids
 * makes kvs backend raise an exception if duplicate is requested
 * ensures kvs backend doesn't allow update of id
 * makes sure that kvs is reset between tests
 * cleans up a few imports
 * fixes bug 927291
 * fixes bug 928659

Change-Id: Ia6eb1961796cbde7ed57a75cd9394d77c88cf655

'}]
commit_message:
Call setgroups() before setuid() and setgid().

Fixes bug 989569.

This patch ensures that the list of groups is completely reset when dropping
privileges.

Change-Id: I049f75e66e08a4a6361504b013bc68c4c38ef093

[{'created': '2012-02-07 23:59:49.000000000', 'message': 'nova-rootwrap: wait() for return code before exit

nova-rootwrap does not wait() for the subprocess it executes to complete before
returning its return code. This often ends up in 0 being returned regardless of
failure/success and causing unforeseen problems in Nova.

Fixes bug #928566

Change-Id: I9b6d85c747513086d0e774cb92ba403886b3283c
'}, {'created': '2012-02-08 00:15:23.000000000', 'message': 'nova-rootwrap: wait() for return code before exit

nova-rootwrap does not wait() for the subprocess it executes to complete before
returning its return code. This often ends up in 0 being returned regardless of
failure/success and causing unforeseen problems in Nova.

Fixes bug #928566

Change-Id: I9b6d85c747513086d0e774cb92ba403886b3283c
'}]
commit_message:
nova-rootwrap: wait() for return code before exit

nova-rootwrap does not wait() for the subprocess it executes to complete before
returning its return code. This often ends up in 0 being returned regardless of
failure/success and causing unforeseen problems in Nova.

Fixes bug #928566

Change-Id: I9b6d85c747513086d0e774cb92ba403886b3283c

subject: Fix xvpvncproxy error in nova-all (lp#928489)

[{'created': '2012-02-03 18:39:19.000000000', 'message': 'Fix xvpvncproxy error in nova-all

Running nova-all, I see:

  2012-02-03 13:09:29,102 ERROR nova [-] Failed to load nova-xvpvncproxy
  (nova): TRACE: Traceback (most recent call last):
  (nova): TRACE:   File "./bin/nova-all", line 70, in <module>
  (nova): TRACE:     servers.append(service.Service.create(binary=binary))
  (nova): TRACE:   File "/home/markmc/git/openstack/nova/nova/service.py", line 237, in create
  (nova): TRACE:     manager = FLAGS.get('%s_manager' % topic, None)
  ...
  (nova): TRACE:     raise NoSuchOptError(opt_name, group)
  (nova): TRACE: NoSuchOptError: no such option: xvpvncproxy_manager

xvp_proxy is a WSGIService, not a Service.

Change-Id: I073d6536134a4fc8d819c808a6c96b02390b556d
'}, {'created': '2012-02-07 21:33:29.000000000', 'message': 'Fix xvpvncproxy error in nova-all (lp#928489)

Running nova-all, I see:

  (nova): TRACE: NoSuchOptError: no such option: xvpvncproxy_manager

xvp_proxy is a WSGIService, not a Service.

Change-Id: I073d6536134a4fc8d819c808a6c96b02390b556d
'}]
commit_message:
Fix xvpvncproxy error in nova-all (lp#928489)

Running nova-all, I see:

  (nova): TRACE: NoSuchOptError: no such option: xvpvncproxy_manager

xvp_proxy is a WSGIService, not a Service.

Change-Id: I073d6536134a4fc8d819c808a6c96b02390b556d

to glance client binary.

commit_message:
Remove ajaxterm from Nova

Removes copy of ajaxterm code, nova-ajax-console-proxy,
and support for get_ajax_console from Nova proper.

Implements blueprint remove-ajaxterm
Fixes bug 917963

Change-Id: I2c0ff427c53c0f63a18b10475d6b4cbe9a085d83

[{'created': '2012-02-08 06:41:33.000000000', 'message': 'Added logging to select areas of melange.

The biggest change here is that now by default SQLAlchemy will
not echo every query. This can still be turned on, but it is very
verbose. More specific log lines should be added for debugging after
this change.

Change-Id: Ia51933d268412ae61cf2df8c355c0fa1b365d57f
'}]
commit_message:
Added logging to select areas of melange.

The biggest change here is that now by default SQLAlchemy will
not echo every query. This can still be turned on, but it is very
verbose. More specific log lines should be added for debugging after
this change.

Change-Id: Ia51933d268412ae61cf2df8c355c0fa1b365d57f

Keystone Auth supports both passwords and API keys. At the moment, there is no way to distinguish between the two in python-novaclient, but that is something that will need to be addressed.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-19 17:54:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Josh: could you elaborate on the reasons? I can't see why it's wrong, and I'd like to :) Thanks."}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2011-12-19 17:58:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Keystone will accept both a password and an API key for authentication. Right now, there is no way to distinguish between the two in novaclient, but that is something we will need to add down the road.'}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-19 20:15:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

there is no API_KEY in keystone.  There is a proof of concept of a rackspace specific extension that is going to be removed since there isn't time to finish it during essex timeframe"}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2011-12-20 09:16:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I can't see API_KEY in Keystone too, so any pointer appreciated, or please reset this review. :)"}, {'account_id': 112, 'date': '2011-12-31 00:00:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think removing api_key is correct for openstack.  we have no such thing as an api key in openstack'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-03 14:14:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Rename api_key to password

Change I37e57e83187e3dd28c55ad33073e0ff7e4df5d76 removed the last usage of
api_key as a keyword argument, therefore it is now safe to rename it.

Change-Id: Iccfcfbc58eccfa12994dfd5f07f5b4719e85b2ef
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien.danjou@enovance.com>

subject: Fix for bug 803086 Moving the plugin_provider attribute into Quantum.conf, deprecating plugins.ini
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 233, 'name': 'Brad Hall', 'email': 'brad@nicira.com', 'username': 'bgh'}, {'_account_id': 261, 'name': 'Salvatore Orlando', 'email': 'salv.orlando@gmail.com', 'username': 'salvatore-orlando'}, {'_account_id': 447, 'name': 'dan wendlandt', 'email': 'dan@nicira.com', 'username': 'danwent'}, {'_account_id': 452, 'name': 'Somik Behera', 'email': 'somik@nicira.com', 'username': 'somikbehera'}, {'_account_id': 1726, 'name': 'Ghe Rivero', 'email': 'ghe.rivero@gmail.com', 'username': 'ghe.rivero'}, {'_account_id': 2315, 'name': 'Luiz Ozaki', 'email': 'luiz.ozaki@gmail.com', 'username': 'luiz-ozaki'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 233, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Yeah, I agree.. lets target this for essex-2 so that we don't have to do any quick patching of the stuff already submitted to devstack."}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Code looks good'}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Me too'}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That's perfectly understandable."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

This is the way in which I believe the code in this changeset behaves: it looks for the plugin in quantum.conf, and then if the plugin class is not found in quantum.conf looks for it in plugins.ini (logging a deprecation message).

I'm afraid I don't fully understand what needs to be addressed."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

One minor typo in the README, otherwise the code looks good.  

I think the real question is whether we want to submit this so close to a milestone release.  I am worried about it breaking automated scripts and documentation.  For example, I know this will break the work Brad did for quantum and devstack, which just got integrated into the devstack repo.  I'm not sure, but this make break other Jenkins work that Carl has done.  Perhaps we should just wait until we branch essex-1, then merge this into trunk."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

I'm still in favor of putting this patch in.  What do others think?  If so, I'd like to do it ASAP, so we don't get too close to essex-2."}, {'account_id': 452, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I agree with Luis's recommendation. That's usually the best way to deprecate an API that was been already released.

In this case while a config file is not an API, I believe it behaves the same way as other plugin writers took our diablo recommendations and are writing their own plugins.

I would be in favor of leaving both formats for one release and then removing the plugins.ini completely."}, {'account_id': 1726, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2315, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I see that there is some concerns about this... Why not make the plugins.ini configuration compatible with the old (plugins.ini) and new ones goes on the quantum.conf ?

So for now, both quantum.conf and plugins.ini will fetch the plugin configuration.

Then others will have time to fix / move the configuration from plugins.ini to quantum.conf and in some release we remove plugins.ini for good.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-02-08 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]

commit_message:
Update cfg from openstack-common

Use openstack-common's update.py script to pull in some recent changes:

 * Add the Mapping interface to cfg.ConfigOpts
 * Add support to cfg for disabling interspersed args

Make use of both of these in nova/flags.py.

Add some dire warnings to HACKING about directly modifying the copy of
openstack-common code. I'm confident they won't be ignored :-)

Change-Id: I7ef75d18922c0bbb8844453b48cad0418034bc11

commit_message:
Add REVERT_RESIZE server status to v2

In order to communicate to the user what state their instances is in
after a revertResize action is triggered, we should apply the state
'REVERT_RESIZE'. This will help fix bug 924371.

Change-Id: I181d463234949bbc141a0a62c539a0f96eb69ead

Thanks for reviewing our codes.
Based on your comments, we modified all bare-metal codes including unit test code even though only partial codes are shown as modified codes and others are shown as new codes because we had some problems to push to git.
Please let us know if you have questions/troubles.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2011-12-05 19:41:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Mikyung:

You have a merge conflict in the Authors file."}, {'account_id': 221, 'date': '2011-12-06 17:57:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-28 19:54:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(4 inline comments)

There are a few things inline I pointed out. Many of the comments I made apply to multiple files, so please check over the whole patchset.

First off, I want to make sure I'm not missing something conceptually: you set connection_type to 'baremetal' and baremetal_driver to 'tilera'. It then loads up ProxyConnection which talks to BareMetalDom. BareMetalDom is what uses the 'tilera' driver to actually do work. Please correct me if that's wrong.

Assuming my understanding is correct, I want to ask: why is the proxy class necessary?

I would also prefer to see connection_type set to 'tilera', not 'baremetal', and to not use a baremetal_driver flag at all. The class imported when 'tilera' is used can be a subclass of any common baremetal functionality.

Please don't get my questioning tone to mean I don't like this code. I'm extremely excited to see this feature getting done!"}, {'account_id': 221, 'date': '2012-01-12 23:40:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 221, 'date': '2012-01-12 23:44:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thanks, Brian!
After modifying codes based on your comments, I uploaded patch Set 5.

First, architecture concept follows ProxyConnection -> BareMetalDom -> Tilera driver.
To avoid naming confusion, we can think ProxyConnection as BareMetalConnection: BareMetalConnection -> BareMetalDom -> Tilrea driver.

The first ProxyConnection (BareMetalConnection) is needed for basic services such as spawn/destroy/reboot for each machine.
Except domain stuffs, basic functionalities are same to libvirt/connection.py.
For different domain management, that part was separated to the BareMetalDom.

The second BareMetalDom is needed for managing domain status as libvirt does for KVM or Xen.
Because baremetal domain is not supported by libvirt, virtual domain management method was newly written using file I/O.
This can be upgraded or used by a new domain manager.

The third Tilera driver is one example among several baremetal types.
Baremetal type can be tilera, arm, or other pxe_boot node, something like that.
Currently only tilera driver is written and this tilera.py code manages actual booting/terminating of tilera node.
But other type can be attached for using same BareMetalConnection and BareMetalDom.
To apply this to other baremetal type, we are using baremetal_driver flag.
So we didn't set connection_type as tilera directly, but baremetal."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-25 20:47:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Do not submit

(19 inline comments)

I made several style-related comments in a few files. Please address those issues across all of your code. Additionally, your python source files should not be executable.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-25 21:09:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I would also like to see some documentation with this patch.'}, {'account_id': 221, 'date': '2012-01-28 06:42:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 221, 'date': '2012-01-28 06:53:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Thanks for reviewing and pointing out error/unnecessary parts!
Unused import, import block, HACKING docstring, unnecessary log, unnecessary backslashes, and i18n portions had been updated. Also file mode was changed. Unit test problem was resolved after updating code base on the latest version.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-29 17:57:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (9 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 221, 'date': '2012-01-30 22:17:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 221, 'date': '2012-01-30 22:27:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Based on Patch Set 6's review, unnecessary statements/logs were deleted and some import line's position was changed in the block. Log messages were modified to a single line and breaking lines or unnecessary dashes were removed. For subprocess.Popen() comment, reply/question is sent."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-30 22:37:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

This seems like a good candidate for a feature exception per my earlier email: It is an extra driver that doesn't touch core code. It would be nice to make it official via an email to the list though. Could you send a quick email to the list requesting the FFE?"}, {'account_id': 221, 'date': '2012-01-31 19:09:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-02 21:20:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Not sure why we're adding project_id arguments to some of the functions and then not using them, but I'm going to assume that's for an upcoming patch."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-03 20:05:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Also, could you start using more useful commit messages? A header with a description of the fix, a little info about how it was fixed, and a reference to the bug would be nice.

For example, I would have done this:

Allows QuantumManager delete ports under load

 * Adds project_id to various calls because ...
 * Improves exception handling of ...
 * Fixes bug 926282"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-02-03 20:06:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

At a glance this bug seems to reintroduce bug 922319, which was previously fixed.  Need to review the rest of the patch as well."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-02-03 20:12:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Dan: whoops, guess we need to reconcile with trunk again. This was the diff we had working locally. 

Vish: sure'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-02-03 20:14:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

For several reasons, please do not approve this patch.  It breaks existing Quantum Manager functionality that other people are relying on.  See comments.  

Also, are you sure the problem is not solved by the following patch, which handles a race condition in port deletion with Quantum?   https://review.openstack.org/#change,3655

I've been working closely with Troy to on this issue, and last I heard, this fix was sufficient.  Has something new popped up?  If so, I'd like to troubleshoot the actual error, rather than just introduce code that ignores the error."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-02-03 20:23:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Dan, perhaps I pushed this prematurely. I was trying to reconcile the divergence between a branch we were testing here and master, and this patch was the result

With that said, we already include the changes you mentioned, and we were still having port deallocation issues. The above patch did fix it in the interim, but I can see where you're talking about regarding the problem. We'll regroup and look again."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-02-03 20:28:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-02-03 21:42:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-02-03 21:54:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I'll talk to Koelker about the other note you made"}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-02-07 19:38:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-02-07 19:39:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Turned out this was a bad idea'}]

Fixes problems identified in: https://review.openstack.org/#change,3796'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-02-07 10:52:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I have the same patch locally, but it is now part of a much larger patch set that greatly improves the unit testing coverage of Quantum Manager.  +1-ing this patch so it can go in quickly without waiting for a review of all of my other unit tests + fixes.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-02-07 12:27:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Does this actually work for you?  

In my testing, I found that the api_call decorator was "stealing" the kwargs from all of the client methods, meaning that filter_ops always seemed to be None.  I have this working now in a local branch by tweaking the decorator logical, but perhaps I'm missing something.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-02-07 15:26:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Not sure, we hacked it into our staging env last night and then fired off our builders, and left them. Now that i look at the api_call decorator I see that its eating kwargs. I'll fix that quick too."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-02-07 15:31:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-02-07 17:04:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Yup, this is closer to what I had (I deleted the two items from kwargs, to mirror previous behavior a bit closer, but I don't think it matters)."}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-02-07 17:05:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

kwargs.pop will remove them from the dict'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-02-07 17:06:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Course my fingers are a bit <return> happy today.

kwargs.pop will remove them from the dict, if they are left in the underlying calls will fail since they'll be getting unexpected kwargs."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-02-07 17:21:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Yup, you're right.  btw, I have a big patch of quantum unit tests coming down the pipe. :)"}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-02-07 19:21:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Renamed all user-facing cases of "tenant" to "project".

This required a little more refactoring than expected because I
wanted to make the url slug also say "project", which required
changing the panel slug, which in turn required changing the name of
the panel directory, and then it seemed silly not to make the template
directory match.

Fixed bug 909495.

Change-Id: I9da3b544b46f507a223a44c256d0008c8674ab3b

commit_message:
Syspanel instance display corrections.

  * Adds support for the "all_tenants" query parameter to the nova API,
    Fixing bug 914001.
  * Pulls in flavor-correlation code. Fixes bug 927949.
  * Adds unit test for admin instances view.

Change-Id: Iee9c018da02d83f58749141296ec9d618b2335d3

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-02-07 15:53:00.000000000', 'message': "Fix support for --flagfile argument

Recent changes broke support for the --flagfile argument. It would attempt
to find the argument and then pull off the filename portion, but it would
only skip one letter, instead of the full argument name. The resulting
error would be:

Change-Id: Ic252b0c778774a7ea3e24a9ed8b182deb5987f65
OSError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'lagfile=../nova.conf'
"}]
commit_message:
Fix support for --flagfile argument

Recent changes broke support for the --flagfile argument. It would attempt
to find the argument and then pull off the filename portion, but it would
only skip one letter, instead of the full argument name. The resulting
error would be:

Change-Id: Ic252b0c778774a7ea3e24a9ed8b182deb5987f65
OSError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'lagfile=../nova.conf'

commit_message:
Fixes LP#903978 - Write testcases for test_server_actions (boundary)

Adds test cases for reboot and rebuild of non-existing server

Made a few style-related fixups
Changed the error response code from 422 to 404 and converted the indentation
to 4 space width.
Added nonexistant server action tests for reboot and rebuild
Restored the deleted new lines.

Change-Id: I61d0ff23c90811467e7f710450e23bee53cf2e22

Added nonexistant server action tests for reboot and rebuild

Change-Id: I61d0ff23c90811467e7f710450e23bee53cf2e22

This means you can have your vlan_interface be different on
different hosts machines by setting vlan_interface differently
on each host.

 * Allow non-homogenous vlan networks
 * Fixes bug 833426
 * Includes failing test for linux_net

(cherry picked from commit 8efe15209aaee6b15c8edb21362c08137294a7de)

Resolved Conflicts:

	nova/tests/test_linux_net.py

Change-Id: I68aa52e745318cedfbefb6fbac8187fceb1ae06b
'}]
commit_message:
Provides flag override for vlan interface

This means you can have your vlan_interface be different on
different hosts machines by setting vlan_interface differently
on each host.

 * Allow non-homogenous vlan networks
 * Fixes bug 833426
 * Includes failing test for linux_net

(cherry picked from commit 8efe15209aaee6b15c8edb21362c08137294a7de)

Resolved Conflicts:

	nova/tests/test_linux_net.py

Change-Id: I68aa52e745318cedfbefb6fbac8187fceb1ae06b

commit_message:
Store the correct tenant_id/project_id

Melange stores the networks in the nova table so quantum manager
can use it, this makes it store the correct value so deallocation
will work.

Change-Id: Icafacca559570c6de679fbb126700519a19b77ee

Why was this code approved?  There are functional problems and even a runtime error in here.  I'm guessing there are zero tests for the functionality in question, which begs the question - why weren't tests included?

I'm going to file a bug and remedy this."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-02-06 23:55:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

You're right.  Its a complete fluke that my functional devstack testing passed (Quantum didn't get the filter string at all, but I tore down the VMs in the same order that quantum returned then in the get_ports API call, which made my devstack tests pass).

The bigger unit testing issue is that there is no "fake quantum server" object that stubs out this part of the code, so this code itself is only tested via our devstack automation.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-02-07 00:01:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Dan: I'll let you fix the problems, then.  I suggest changing filter_ops=None in the signatures of list_networks and list_ports, and calling do_request with params=filter_ops.  The append_filter_params method is redundant - do_request already supports parameter encoding."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-02-07 00:06:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yes, I will fix this.  I really appreciate the catch, it was a totally bone-headed error... I guess submitting code at 1am is a bad idea :)'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-02-07 03:21:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

FWIW I uploaded the fix quick to https://review.openstack.org/#change,3843'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-02-06 09:32:34.000000000', 'message': "bug 927507: fix quantum manager get_port_by_attachment

- makes query efficient by using Quantum API filters (new in API v1.1)
- fixes correctness issue where we did not handle case where network
did not exist in quantum (note: this was masked by a quantum bug that
will be fixed once this change is into nova).

Also included a few other minor things in this patchset:
1) make get_instance_nw_info use network label from DB, which is already
available, rather than calling out to quantum just to get the name.
2) quantum manager was not properly cleaning up VIFs in the nova db.  This fixes that.
3) set 'bridge' in nw_info dictionary to the empty string, to clearly indicate that this value is ignored by Quantum Manager.

Change-Id: Ia1cbb5232f8ce373b605979902f88d7528d3e456
"}]
commit_message:
bug 927507: fix quantum manager get_port_by_attachment

- makes query efficient by using Quantum API filters (new in API v1.1)
- fixes correctness issue where we did not handle case where network
did not exist in quantum (note: this was masked by a quantum bug that
will be fixed once this change is into nova).

Also included a few other minor things in this patchset:
1) make get_instance_nw_info use network label from DB, which is already
available, rather than calling out to quantum just to get the name.
2) quantum manager was not properly cleaning up VIFs in the nova db.  This fixes that.
3) set 'bridge' in nw_info dictionary to the empty string, to clearly indicate that this value is ignored by Quantum Manager.

Change-Id: Ia1cbb5232f8ce373b605979902f88d7528d3e456

commit_message:
Fix _poll_bandwidth_usage if no network on vif

Bugfix for lp901819

Move DB lookups out of the virt layer for bw usage.
Migrate to storing the mac address in the table.
Only lookup network label when sending usage events.
Attempt to use info_cache for label lookup before
    punting to rpc call.

Change-Id: Iffb4bc220804be7d5fe26d6416b90cd747b72753

[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-03 19:50:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(4 inline comments)

Minor stuff inline

make sure to check for pep8 with ./run_tests.sh -p"}, {'account_id': 2383, 'date': '2012-02-03 20:03:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-02-03 20:15:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2383, 'date': '2012-02-03 20:22:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-02-03 20:39:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Just one problem with a test. Comments inline"}, {'account_id': 2383, 'date': '2012-02-03 20:54:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-02-03 21:11:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Great job.'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-02-03 21:12:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2383, 'date': '2012-02-03 21:18:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-02-03 21:37:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

The functionality looks great, but the tests are too high-level.  There are already comprehensive tests for retrieving image and flavor details, and the link changes do not suggest test additions at that level.

Please consider writing tests that directly target each of the 3 functions you have changed and the 1 that was added to nova.api.openstack.common, as well a test that targets the change to nova.api.openstack.common."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-02-03 21:39:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: No score

My apologies, the last reference in the previous review message should have been 'nova.api.openstack.compute.views.images'."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-02-03 21:40:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I managed to accidentally change the score to 0 in the last message.  Fixing..."}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-02-03 21:54:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Maru, unit testing private helper functions requires injecting implementation details into tests which results in fragile tests. Tests should not break if the implementation changes and the behavior is the same. Testing at a higher level is preferable, imo.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-02-03 22:01:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(4 inline comments)

Comments on the new flags. Code looks good"}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-02-03 22:33:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Naveed, I respectfully disagree with your assertion that writing unit tests for private helper functions is not desirable.  Effectively evaluating the quality of low-level functionality at the integration testing level (which the tests in the current patch qualify as) is very difficult, due to the explosion of possible states created by all the interacting components.  If functionality is not amenable to unit testing, a rewrite for testability is almost always preferable to writing and maintaining higher-level tests.

I recognize that rewriting for testability may be outside the scope of this change, but at the very least, a unit test should be written for _update_link_prefix.  It has no external dependencies and should be trivially testable.'}, {'account_id': 2383, 'date': '2012-02-03 22:34:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-02-04 22:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Maru, I would refer you to what the documentation for google's c++ testing framework says on testing private interfaces: http://code.google.com/p/googletest/wiki/AdvancedGuide#Testing_Private_Code

I do not expect to change your mind, but at least it might give you a new perspective :)"}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-02-05 05:05:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Naveed: I'm unclear as to why a testing strategy for C++ (even from Google) would necessarily be considered relevant for how to test in Python.  Dynamic and static languages have markedly different implementation semantics, and this extends to testing.

I prefer to verify as much functionality as possible in unit tests, and this frequently requires testing private functionality.  The more exhaustive the lower-level functionality can be tested, the fewer paths have to be tested at a higher-level (including public interfaces) to ensure good coverage and quality code.  Of course, YMMV."}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-02-06 19:18:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-02-06 22:08:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-02-06 22:14:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

LGTM'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-06 22:37:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/1124/ : SUCCESS

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/871/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2629/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-06 22:37:25.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-06 22:44:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

[{'created': '2012-02-06 22:21:54.000000000', 'message': 'Remove quantum CLI console script.

The quantum CLI console script is now installed by the
python-quantumclient project, so remove it from the quantum project's
setup.py. Fixes bug 925596.

Test by running "python setup.py install --root <somedir>" and
checking that <somedir>/usr/bin/quantum is not created.

Change-Id: Icd7eff79c8d30511693942a859334829cbf0d9af
Signed-off-by: Bob Kukura <rkukura@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Remove quantum CLI console script.

The quantum CLI console script is now installed by the
python-quantumclient project, so remove it from the quantum project's
setup.py. Fixes bug 925596.

Test by running "python setup.py install --root <somedir>" and
checking that <somedir>/usr/bin/quantum is not created.

Change-Id: Icd7eff79c8d30511693942a859334829cbf0d9af
Signed-off-by: Bob Kukura <rkukura@redhat.com>

Other drivers specifically the HPSanISCSI Driver needs the exact same approach, like assign this host to the volume. I think it's a generic name and something that you have to configure independently on the san side. But was wondering if we may want to pass in say a 'hostname' in the initiator() callback so that driver could optionally use that instead of the ip. Just a thought. 

On a side note I need to update the san drivers with some patches I have, hopefully will try to get some in the bug squash day"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-31 22:15:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Mark: will address your comments ASAP.  Marking this WIP for now 

In regards to the wrapping of execute.  There was an execute already in libvirt utils, but libvirt wasn't using it. The purpose of the fake libvirt seemed to be to mock out all of the things that were hitting the actual system.  So my choices were to find all of the tests that were calling volume related commands and mock out execute in all of them, or actually switch to using libvirt_utils.execute which is "automatically" mocked in the tests.  There were three instances of execute so it seemed cleaner to just switch them all.'}, {'account_id': 838, 'date': '2012-02-02 18:57:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

[{'created': '2012-01-31 19:31:07.000000000', 'message': 'Add initiator to initialize_connection

Some volumes need to know the name of the initiator that will be
connecting to the iscsi volume.  This adds a call down to the hypervisor
driver to get the ip and the initiator name for the vm before calling
initialize connection. This connection is passed down to the volume
driver so that it can be used to authenticate when the hypervisor
tries to connect to the volume.

 * Adds initiator initialize_connection
 * Makes a call to driver to get initiator name and ip address
 * Add tests for the driver calls
 * Cleans up libvirt use of execute
 * Fixes bug 924461

Change-Id: I5b6a2dd84560c7f7b447571e0abf0993e5512ca0

commit_message:
Add initiator to initialize_connection

Some volumes need to know the name of the initiator that will be
connecting to the iscsi volume.  This adds a call down to the hypervisor
driver to get the ip and the initiator name for the vm before calling
initialize connection. This connection is passed down to the volume
driver so that it can be used to authenticate when the hypervisor
tries to connect to the volume.

 * Adds initiator initialize_connection
 * Makes a call to driver to get initiator name and ip address
 * Gets initiator from openiscsi for libvirt
 * Gets initiator from config for xenapi
 * Add tests for the driver calls
 * Fixes bug 924461

Change-Id: I5b6a2dd84560c7f7b447571e0abf0993e5512ca0

commit_message:
Allows nova to read files as root

 * Adds a rootwrap filter to limit readable files
 * Adds a utils method to read a file as root
 * adds tests to verify the additions work

Change-Id: Ic1ffb6f72f9b73795d5f39fac719842e6bdf16dd

commit_message:
Interface network_id also requires tenant

The server was updated to require passing the network's tenant_id
when creating interfaces, this updates the tests and the client
to do the same.

Change-Id: I58c71c52999060cc3a3a4d36928e9f07cc9d6dfd

subject: bug 924266: connection_type and firewall_driver flags mismatch
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 748, 'name': 'Armando Migliaccio', 'email': 'armamig@gmail.com', 'username': 'armando-migliaccio'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-01-31 16:08:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I expected this failure, because this one

https://review.openstack.org/#change,3576

has to go through first.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-31 16:26:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-31 17:20:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm a little worried about this change, just because it will break existing installs. I wonder if there is somewhere that we can check the flag and change the default if the driver type is set, just so we don't break existing installs."}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-02-01 11:45:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think that attempting what you're saying may lead to unpredictable results (what if the lack of the driver definition is intentional or just a misconfiguration?)

The bottom problem here is the fact that there is no clear way to deprecate default flag values, let alone mark a flag for deletion.

What about we raise a clear exception (at the very beginning) if the virt driver is not running with the firewall driver that is supposed to run with? 

This will still break existing installs, but the gain of this approach is twofold:

1) the admin knows exactly what's going on, straight away.
2) if there is an accidental misconfiguration, this does not lead to obscure failures, that might be potentially occur all the way down the code path of spawning an instance.

Shortly, I will be pushing a changeset that shows what I mean. As you all know, between words and LOCs...code always wins :)"}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-02-01 12:37:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-02-01 16:43:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

Looks good, assuming Vish is convinced.  (See minor nit in inline, though)'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-01 17:01:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'm ok with this, we really need to put this in the release notes though. It will also require a change in ubuntu and smokestacks packages.

Vish"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-01 17:01:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

adding dan prince to see if he has an opinion.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-01 17:08:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

suggesstion inline"}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-02-01 21:28:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

Hi Vish,

it looks like 

FLAGS['firewall_driver'].SetDefault('nova.virt.libvirt.firewall.IptablesFirewallDriver')

does not have any effect on the global variable. 

I'll dig a bit more tomorrow, but I wanted to double-check with you; maybe the last changes on nova flags have altered the expected behavior?"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-01 21:43:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

darn, maybe it needs a reparse or something.  Let me ask mark if there is a right way to do this with config.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-02-01 22:11:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Vish's SetDefault suggestion should work

Try sticking some prints in _get() in cfg and you should see whatever you passed to SetDefault being returned here:

	if default is not None:
            return default

If not, something else like self.flags(firewall_driver=...) in tests is overriding it"}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-02-06 15:56:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-06 16:49:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Good Deal'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-06 16:59:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/1116/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/1244/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/865/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/2623/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-06 16:59:39.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-02-06 17:05:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/nova-tarball/1896/ : SUCCESS'}]

commit_message:
bug 924266: connection_type and firewall_driver flags mismatch

If connection_type is None, the default firewall driver should not
be nova.virt.libvirt.firewall.IptablesFirewallDriver; it should
either be None or the base one.

If this fix gets through, devstack needs to be fixed accordingly.
See review below for details.

https://review.openstack.org/#change,3576

Change-Id: I58dabc50be2d5cdcd509b2ac89a5bd0f78251bd0

commit_message:
Rename inst in _create_image, and pass instance to log msgs.

This renames inst in _create_image to the more consistant name
"instance". It also passes the instance through log messages in this
method, and removes the instance name from the translatable text
for the corresponding log messages.

Change-Id: I9a085198d3bea5d073f4297cc57c84dc7fcb0349

subject: Re-run nova-manage under sudo if unable to read conffile
messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-04 00:17:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I find this very useful, although I really don't know about the security implications.  With a recent change that I made here:

https://review.openstack.org/#change,3780

we could alternatively read the conf file with utils.read_file_as_root(), although we might have to change the flagfile loading slightly."}, {'account_id': 518, 'date': '2012-02-04 00:23:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

It doesn't overstep any security boundaries that the user can't already stroll right over, so securitywise, I see no problem.

As for reading the conffile as root: Whether we can read the conffile is really just a simple heuristic. Actually becoming nova is necessary to make sure created files are correctly owned by Nova (or can even be created at all). Case in point: The initial sqlite database created by "nova-manage db sync": If you just "sudo nova-manage db sync", it'll be owned by root, so subsequent nova services will have trouble writing to it, and your own user won't be able to create it. The only correct user to do that is the nova user. I imagine there are other, similar issues.'}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-02-04 19:23:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

[{'created': '2012-02-03 23:27:01.000000000', 'message': "Re-run nova-manage under sudo if unable to read conffile

Having to manually sudo to the nova user to make things work is
tedious. Make it so that if we can't read the conffile, we just
re-exec under sudo.

Fixes bug 805695

Change-Id: I322cece80ca757c69147fb3f8474ad137d9bff82
"}]
commit_message:
Re-run nova-manage under sudo if unable to read conffile

Having to manually sudo to the nova user to make things work is
tedious. Make it so that if we can't read the conffile, we just
re-exec under sudo.

Fixes bug 805695

Change-Id: I322cece80ca757c69147fb3f8474ad137d9bff82

revisions:
[{'created': '2011-12-15 07:36:41.000000000', 'message': "Early majority responses.

This should be considered experimental at this point. I want to get
feedback such as any concerns with returning early in some cases.

The jist is that once a proxy write request knows the status it will
return, that it should return it and leave any remaining backends
requests to finish in the background.

For example with an object put on a 3 replica cluster: Once the
proxy receives two identical statuses from the backends, it knows
that's the status it's going to return, so it does. If just one
backend is being slow, it won't slow down the response to the user.
With some of the timeouts being 60 seconds, this can dramatically
reduce request times.

The only thing I can think of where an early return can't be done is
with a container delete. If any of the backends returns 409, we
should return 409 (I actually don't know if we even do that now, to
be honest).

Another concern I have with this patch is that the unit tests are
taking 37% longer even with the early return logic off though the
functional tests run in the usual time.

Change-Id: I3a4aa4870b5f41c94d2a117a3472907fc8a2bfe0
"}]
commit_message:
Early majority responses.

This should be considered experimental at this point. I want to get
feedback such as any concerns with returning early in some cases.

The jist is that once a proxy write request knows the status it will
return, that it should return it and leave any remaining backends
requests to finish in the background.

For example with an object put on a 3 replica cluster: Once the
proxy receives two identical statuses from the backends, it knows
that's the status it's going to return, so it does. If just one
backend is being slow, it won't slow down the response to the user.
With some of the timeouts being 60 seconds, this can dramatically
reduce request times.

The only thing I can think of where an early return can't be done is
with a container delete. If any of the backends returns 409, we
should return 409 (I actually don't know if we even do that now, to
be honest).

Another concern I have with this patch is that the unit tests are
taking 37% longer even with the early return logic off though the
functional tests run in the usual time.

Change-Id: I3a4aa4870b5f41c94d2a117a3472907fc8a2bfe0

[{'created': '2012-02-02 19:03:09.000000000', 'message': 'Provides flag override for vlan interface

This means you can have your vlan_interface be different on
different hosts machines by setting vlan_interface differently
on each host.

 * Allow non-homogenous vlan networks
 * Fixes bug 833426
 * Includes failing test for linux_net

Change-Id: I2f0d43c1366f88a8832a779c4065b37dd1a5bdf8
'}]
commit_message:
Provides flag override for vlan interface

This means you can have your vlan_interface be different on
different hosts machines by setting vlan_interface differently
on each host.

 * Allow non-homogenous vlan networks
 * Fixes bug 833426
 * Includes failing test for linux_net

Change-Id: I2f0d43c1366f88a8832a779c4065b37dd1a5bdf8

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-02-03 22:34:23.000000000', 'message': "X_USER is deprecated in favor of X_USER_ID

Addressed bug 926372

Eventually, we should stop supporting X_USER because it is *supposed* to
be the user's login name rather than their id. But this change preserves
the old behavior for stability.

For more info checkout keystone/middleware/auth_token.py in the keystone
project.

Change-Id: Ie837e73f9a592a903af71a426e202f8b6a9ac581
"}]
commit_message:
X_USER is deprecated in favor of X_USER_ID

Addressed bug 926372

Eventually, we should stop supporting X_USER because it is *supposed* to
be the user's login name rather than their id. But this change preserves
the old behavior for stability.

For more info checkout keystone/middleware/auth_token.py in the keystone
project.

Change-Id: Ie837e73f9a592a903af71a426e202f8b6a9ac581

P.S. Eventually, I realized it is better to make little changes to server side. <https://review.openstack.org/#change,3570>
Detailed description is <https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/924093>'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-31 23:09:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Much better.'}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2012-02-01 06:34:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2012-02-01 06:54:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

This version make little changes based on comments below.
<https://review.openstack.org/#change,3570>

The comment is "any parenthesis should not be included to  column name of PrettyTable", so changes are "mem(mb)" -> "memory_mb" and "disk(gb)" -> "disk_gb".'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-02-01 16:32:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

This looks OK to me, but it looks overall as if these two patches are adding a new feature to both nova and novaclient.  Is there a base bug report (besides 924093) you can point at to justify letting this in during feature freeze?'}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2012-02-02 02:56:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hello Kevin, Thanks for your comment. This MP is based on <http://etherpad.openstack.org/live-migration-api>,  mentioning this feature. But you are right, especially python-novaclient, I haven't mentioned any at above BP. In addition, the priority of this BP is Low.

Although I think below plan looks good, if you don't think so,  I will abondon this MP. Please let me know your opinion.

1. This MP is merged in Essex in timeframe.

2. Make changes manual(docs.openstack.org) to use API in Essex timeframe (currently, manual says using nova-manage).

3. Delete nova-manage live-migration related feature at next release timeframe(if anybody agree with it... I only listen to some of  core devs think that nova-manage should not call computeAPI).

My recommendation is, at least, it is better that <https://review.openstack.org/#change,3570> is merged if I will abondon this MP."}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2012-02-02 04:28:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2012-02-03 04:31:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-02-03 16:10:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

Still concerned that this is being submitted during FF, but I'll defer to others; it's probably not as critical on the client anyway…"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-02-03 19:00:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:
