OK, smokestack should be happy now..'}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2012-01-24 05:02:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-01-24 09:27:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

commit_message:
Add support for pluggable l3 backends

This will allow us to support backends other than linux_net (i.e.
quantum L3 when it is available) for defining L3 connectivity.

Change-Id: I0b2ece2278bd68166741107a88cedd106d1ab651

commit_message:
Add 'all_tenants' filter to GET /servers.

Update the OpenStack API's GET /servers method so that it only returns
servers from a single tenant when an admin account is used.

Adds an 'all_tenants' filter option that can be used to obtain servers
from all tenants (legacy behavior).

Fixes LP Bug # 923218.

Change-Id: I2fd3bd3e2c374ff1aed9c11006585c3f93449c6e

subject: Fixing a rebuild race condition bug.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 177, 'name': 'Alex Meade', 'email': 'mr.alex.meade@gmail.com', 'username': 'alex-meade'}, {'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 616, 'name': 'Mark Washenberger', 'email': 'mark.washenberger@markwash.net', 'username': 'markwash'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 706, 'name': 'Brian Lamar', 'email': 'brian.lamar@rackspace.com', 'username': 'blamar'}, {'_account_id': 998, 'name': 'Naveed Massjouni', 'email': 'naveedm9@gmail.com', 'username': 'ironcamel'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1419, 'name': 'Mike Pittaro', 'email': 'mikeyp@LaHondaResearch.org', 'username': 'mikeyp-3'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-01-24 19:46:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

see my comment re: the new capacity cache"}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-24 21:13:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2012-01-24 21:30:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-01-24 21:31:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-24 21:36:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-24 21:45:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-24 22:44:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

I would sync up with Mark.  We have another fix regarding rebuilding... (the fact that we update instance['image_ref'] on the API side before we attempt a rebuild) and I think that the proper fix for this part is to remove the pulling of image_meta from the manager side.  The API side is already verifying the image but throwing away the image_meta.  The API should, instead, pass the image_meta to the manager... 

(I think)"}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-24 22:59:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Chris, I do not think what you are describing would fix this bug.  This bug is a race condition that happens on the compute.manager side.  The image is valid on the compute.api side when the cast is made to rabbitmq.  Then the image could be deleted.  Then when the compute.manager goes to do the rebuild, the image no longer exists.  Even if the image_meta was provided from the compute.api side, this bug would still exist.'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-24 23:04:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Fair.  The current solution here doesn't solve the problem yet either then.  You have a race condition in between the image_meta pulling and the self.driver.spawn().  The image could have been deleted between the 2 calls.

So, IMO, the overall solution is to remove image_meta pulling from the manager side (let API pass it as an object)... and then catch the exception around driver.spawn pulling the image.

Make sense?"}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-24 23:37:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Chris, good point. I propose a 3rd approach which I will submit shortly as a patch.'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-25 00:12:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1419, 'date': '2012-01-25 01:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-01-25 06:02:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

This looks to me like it will work well especially if the problem is coming from errors propagating out from the virt layer.

I have this change https://review.openstack.org/3392 which I don't really think is a competitor for this fix but might also be relevant at this time."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-25 16:25:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

This looks more appropriate to address this bug.  Are you positive that ImageNotFound is what would be raised inside of driver.spawn when an image is not found, though?  The error could occur in the xen glance plugin.'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-25 16:29:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Chris, I'm positive that _get_image_meta(context, instance['image_ref']) will throw an ImageNotFound exception. If you follow the directions in the attached bug ticket to reproduce the bug, that's what is actually happening."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-26 19:53:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Naveed. You need to rebase this branch against master...


CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in nova/compute/manager.py'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-26 20:16:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-02-01 19:33:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-02-01 20:59:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
Fixing a rebuild race condition bug.

A race condition caused servers to be undeletable and stay in rebuild state.
This patch handles exceptions on compute.manager side and sets the state
of the instances appropriately.

bug: 918958
Change-Id: I7369a63174284c5b9ed257cc129f611163d5841d

subject: Optionally pass a instance uuid to log methods.
messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-01 01:03:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

seems useful.  Two concerns:

1) i don't like having an unnamed field called additional, i would prefer just calling it instance have an extra flag called instance_format="[ instance: %(uuid)s ]" and passing the entire instance object in.  That way it is more explicit and you could theoretically log other fields from the instance object.

2) I am a little worried about the verbosity of our default log message. This probably needs to be addressed in another patch though.'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-02-01 04:49:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-02-01 04:52:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think I've addressed (1). On the length of log messages, I agree that they're long now, but I think that making them terse at the expense of clarity is a mistake. With this patch we can also remove most of the uses of the UUID in free form text, and replace it with something more parsable. That should help with readability."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-02-01 15:54:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Optionally pass a instance uuid to log methods.

This change is intended to make log messages including instance
uuids consistent. This eases operational support, as when a
customer asks for the history of there instance it is a simple
grep operation, instead of the current situation. I have included
a sample use, but will work through adding this to relevant log
messages over time.

Change-Id: I1f61c04f32dbb960471950ac7231313d9d9ced12

commit_message:
Remove Hyper-V support

HyperV has been unmaintained for several releases now. The unit tests
are superficial, we have no way to test it, noone has stepped forward
to maintain it, and for a very long time, we've not had any reports that
it works. Furthermore, many improvements have been made across other
hypervisor drivers that have not been done in the HyperV driver, so even
if it worked, it would only expose a subset of the functionality that
the other drivers do.

Implements blueprint hypervsectomy.

Change-Id: I3160915816a305d7d6bc34790f9deac459b562a9

commit_message:
Fixing a problem where a exception is silenced.

This commit aims to fix a problem that occurs when you ommit the version information
using the python-novaclient 'nova' application through a shell. Nova client throws
the exception UnsupportedVersion, but this exception isn't shown to the user.

Change-Id: I66f3cee98c5e49d3eb4cde45d60139f46c546226

iscsiadm returns 0 if local db contains no target records.  As a result,
no exception is caught and no entry gets created (--op new) before continuing

Change-Id: I39c3574b8d75ca32eba3716efc3b488e596fbaf6

commit_message:
Fix multinode libvirt volume attachment lp #922232

iscsiadm returns 0 if local db contains no target records.  As a result,
no exception is caught and no entry gets created (--op new) before continuing
to login.  Devstack/single-node users avoided this because, apparently, records
are created in initiator db on target creations.

Update: Address smokestack failures if err == None

fixes bug #922232

Change-Id: I39c3574b8d75ca32eba3716efc3b488e596fbaf6

commit_message:
do not require NOVA_VERSION in env, default to 1.1

fixes bug 920474.

the nova client was not defaulting to version 1.1 unless NOVA_VERSION was
set.  This makes version 1.1 the default if NOVA_VERSION is not set in the
environment.

It also makes shell.py usable from a git checkout as in:
  PYTHONPATH=$PWD python novaclient/shell.py image-list

Change-Id: I02b7e060d1c0694639fcb146a7394b92014c140b

Ensure that if the guest agent is not installed, the admin password configuration is
skipped. The fact that either one of 'version' or 'agent_build' is None (or both)
should be an accurate indication of such a condition.

Change-Id: I90213ce28a900a05d7357b8fa647ffbb0928571a
"}]
commit_message:
Bug #923865: (xenapi driver)instance creation fails if no guest agent is avaiable for admin password configuration

Ensure that if the guest agent is not installed, the admin password configuration is
skipped. The fact that either one of 'version' or 'agent_build' is None (or both)
should be an accurate indication of such a condition.

Change-Id: I90213ce28a900a05d7357b8fa647ffbb0928571a

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-02-01 21:36:31.000000000', 'message': 'Keystone config permission should be 0640, not 0644

The docs incorrectly specified that the keystone config permission should be
0644, but that would provide all users on the system access to the mysql
password.

This fixes the typo, and explicitly adds the chmod and chown.

Change-Id: Ia81effd54e1bb4b66b9fd84e4c753fff950ce0bc
'}]
commit_message:
Keystone config permission should be 0640, not 0644

The docs incorrectly specified that the keystone config permission should be
0644, but that would provide all users on the system access to the mysql
password.

This fixes the typo, and explicitly adds the chmod and chown.

Change-Id: Ia81effd54e1bb4b66b9fd84e4c753fff950ce0bc

from the format string resolves this issue.  I verified that the format

commit_message:
Fix VPN ping packet length.

Fix bug 906346.

This patch addresses the typo pointed out in bug 906346.  The ping being
sent was 15 bytes long when it should have been 14.  Removing a pad byte
from the format string resolves this issue.  I verified that the format
described in the code comments (and now the code) was correct using an
OpenVPN connection setup packet capture.

Change-Id: Idbc5e48ede4a8d2836dd1b102a9a0e172540776c

Thanks for looking into this issue -- it's been bothering me for well over a year now. I just have one question -- the reason this was hardcoded is because it's also used in:

plugins/xenserver/xenapi/etc/xapi.d/plugins/objectstore:                sr_rec['other_config']['i18n-key'] == 'local-storage'):

I'm not up to speed on this plugin (or whether or not it's even used anymore) but is there a way for you to take this into consideration?"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-25 01:31:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

pretty sure that objectstore plugin hasn't been in use since the first release of glance (a year ago?)."}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-01-25 11:28:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

As far as I can tell, the objectstore plugin is no longer used. If my memory does not fail me, it was part of the first cut at getting Nova to work with XenServer, and in this case, the streaming of images was taking place in Dom0 rather than DomU; things have moved quite a bit since.

I'd mark it for removal (I can raise another bug and take care of this)."}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-01-25 11:30:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-26 19:54:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
bug 921087: i18n-key and local-storage hard-coded in xenapi

This fix introduces a new flag 'sr_matching_filter', whose default value is
'other-config:i18n-key=local-storage'. This filter is used for finding the
SR on which to install guest instances. The default value is the Local
Storage in default XenServer/XCP installations, and it is what was hard-coded
so far.

To select an SR with a different matching criteria, this flag can be set
to 'other-config:my_favorite_sr=true'. On the other hand, to fall back on
the Default SR, as displayed by XenCenter and as returned by
xenapi.pool.get_default_SR, this flag can be set to to 'default-sr:true'.

This changeset also makes a small code simplification along the way.

Change-Id: Ia5ee438389c59a5ef0b858e8548643d57ef16c77

ensures that there is nothing leftover that will affect tests of other

'}]
commit_message:
Empty connection pool after test_kombu.

Empty the connection pool after the tests in test_kombu have run.  This
ensures that there is nothing leftover that will affect tests of other
implementations that use nova.rpc.amqp (impl_qpid right now).

Change-Id: Ib023722f97a21821869369d0024cf61272267ea3

commit_message:
Clear out RPC connection pool before exit.

Fixes bug 767984.

This patch ensures that pooled connections to a messaging system get
cleaned up before a process that has used the RPC API exits.

Change-Id: I56eca54334075378534a7a5d3434c420319672b4

commit_message:
Ties quantum, melange, and nova network model

get_instance_nw_info() now returns network model, and keeps the network
info cache up to date.
virt shim and translation in place for virts to get at the old stuff

Change-Id: I070ea7d8564af6c644059d1c209542d250d19ddb

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-02-01 16:45:08.000000000', 'message': "optimize libvirt raw image handling. Bug 924970

Tests were seen to time-out on libvirt when raw images were
used, which was due to large disk images being copied around
inefficiently.  A system with standard disks was seen to take
an extra 60s/10G which was a problem with large root and
ephemeral disks.  The changes below attempt to minimize the
I/O in dealing with cached raw images.  These changes should
also help to minimize the disk space used for such images,
by avoiding the naïve copy which undoes the sparseness.

* nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py (_cache_image): Do the
resize here, rather than in _fetch_image(), so that we
can control when the resizing is done, to minimize the
amount of data that needs to be copied.  Also if we're
generating rather than fetching the image, then just
generate in the instance dir too, as this should be faster.
* nova/tests/fake_libvirt_utils.py: Remove the resize
functionality since it's no longer used.
* nova/tests/test_libvirt.py: Likewise.
* nova/virt/libvirt/utils.py (fetch_image): Likewise.
(copy_image): Shell out to cp since it deals better
with sparse files.  Note the above changes avoid sparse
copies, so this is just an ancillary improvement in the area.

Change-Id: I678d125c61aab56c62c668559eb2220d56702952
"}]
commit_message:
optimize libvirt raw image handling. Bug 924970

Tests were seen to time-out on libvirt when raw images were
used, which was due to large disk images being copied around
inefficiently.  A system with standard disks was seen to take
an extra 60s/10G which was a problem with large root and
ephemeral disks.  The changes below attempt to minimize the
I/O in dealing with cached raw images.  These changes should
also help to minimize the disk space used for such images,
by avoiding the naïve copy which undoes the sparseness.

* nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py (_cache_image): Do the
resize here, rather than in _fetch_image(), so that we
can control when the resizing is done, to minimize the
amount of data that needs to be copied.  Also if we're
generating rather than fetching the image, then just
generate in the instance dir too, as this should be faster.
* nova/tests/fake_libvirt_utils.py: Remove the resize
functionality since it's no longer used.
* nova/tests/test_libvirt.py: Likewise.
* nova/virt/libvirt/utils.py (fetch_image): Likewise.
(copy_image): Shell out to cp since it deals better
with sparse files.  Note the above changes avoid sparse
copies, so this is just an ancillary improvement in the area.

Change-Id: I678d125c61aab56c62c668559eb2220d56702952

commit_message:
remove unsupported ec2 extensions

implements blueprint remove-ec2-extensions

* remove deprecated unofficial ec2 admin api
* remove admin api from wsgi/paste
* remove unofficial ec2 call for ajaxterm / update calls
* remove displayName/displayDescription from volumes/instances

Change-Id: If5a5ae26ebb9456a3c7376ff4ff0aa9589be1f5b

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-02-01 18:21:45.000000000', 'message': "Make sure multiple calls to _get_session() aren't nested

Fixes bug 924918

async_call_plugin() acquires a xenapi session as does the nested call to
get_xenapi_host(). This can cause a deadlock if multiple greenthreads
all block waiting for the outer sessions to be freed to allocate the
inner session. This change moves the call to get_xenapi_host() to outside
the with statement to ensure calls to _get_session() aren't nested.

Change-Id: I8f5490f40a9ccaf74a276187f66519a5d5f52b2e
"}]
commit_message:
Make sure multiple calls to _get_session() aren't nested

Fixes bug 924918

async_call_plugin() acquires a xenapi session as does the nested call to
get_xenapi_host(). This can cause a deadlock if multiple greenthreads
all block waiting for the outer sessions to be freed to allocate the
inner session. This change moves the call to get_xenapi_host() to outside
the with statement to ensure calls to _get_session() aren't nested.

Change-Id: I8f5490f40a9ccaf74a276187f66519a5d5f52b2e

commit_message:
Handle Ambiguous Endpoints Correctly

- Added --service_name argument to allow selecting
  endpoints by service name
- Renamed endpoint_name argument to endpoint_type (this breaks
  compatibility)
- Return AmbiguousEndpoints error if more than one endpoint
  matches filter
- Also addresses bug 924052

Use case:
  $ nova --projectid xxx --version 1.1 --password xxx --username xxx --url https://identity.openstackcloud.com/ image-list
  Found more than one valid endpoint. Use a more restrictive filter
  AmbiguousEndpoints: [
    {'serviceName': 'New Cloud', 'region': 'Test', 'publicURL': 'https://test.openstackcloud.com/v1.1/tttt', 'tenantId': 'tttt'},
    {'serviceName': 'Old Cloud', 'publicURL': 'https://servers.openstackcloud.com/v1.0/tttt', 'tenantId': 'tttt'}]

  $ nova --projectid tttt --version 1.1 --password xxx --username xxx --url https://identity.openstackcloud.com/ --service_name 'New Cloud' image-list
  +--------------------------------------+-----------------------------+--------+--------+
  |                  ID                  |             Name            | Status | Server |
  +--------------------------------------+-----------------------------+--------+--------+
  | 346f4039-a81e-4444-9223-4a3d13592a07 | Debian Squeeze (6.0)        | ACTIVE |        |
  | ac8985ea-c09e-4544-82af-eb459a02a6b2 | Fedora 15                   | ACTIVE |        |
  | ddddc02e-92fa-4f44-b36f-55b39bf66a67 | CentOS 5.6                  | ACTIVE |        |
  +--------------------------------------+-----------------------------+--------+--------+

Change-Id: I9a10b9ad5e5b9cf6e762659013496a93a79774db

commit_message:
Fix broken devref docs.

Fix bug 888102.

This patch fixes the documentation generated here:
	http://nova.openstack.org/devref/index.html

There was a typo in a script that resulted in the module names being
invalid and no docs being generated.  This one character patch fixes it
up and makes the docs happy.

Change-Id: I1986e8b468334a1a33264aaec740c4f535a7c30b

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-31 21:56:41.000000000', 'message': 'Use "display_name" in "nova-manage vm list".

Fixes bug 894807.

This patch changes the output of "nova-manage vm list" to use the
display_name for an instance instead of the hostname in the output.
This makes the output consistent with what you get with "nova list".

Change-Id: I3131c5aad8770481bac7731c06110a98b4cc2966
'}]
commit_message:
Use "display_name" in "nova-manage vm list".

Fixes bug 894807.

This patch changes the output of "nova-manage vm list" to use the
display_name for an instance instead of the hostname in the output.
This makes the output consistent with what you get with "nova list".

Change-Id: I3131c5aad8770481bac7731c06110a98b4cc2966

subject: Fix bug #904792
messages:
[{'account_id': 161, 'date': '2012-01-19 13:47:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Seems reasonable.

This will need to be a different change because I need to verify that it works, but in theory adding the flag "--force_dhcp_release=True" would keep one from having to update the leases and restart dnsmasq manually, as it forces dnsmasq to update its leases table when an instance is terminated.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-01-28 14:04:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Good to know Kevin - I'll log a doc bug to track the second change.

subject: Add Melange Support
messages:
[{'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-01-25 22:49:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-01-25 23:34:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Jason, https://review.openstack.org/3435 just beat you to the quantum client bits, can you rebase once that is in?"}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-01-25 23:46:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Yea as soon as it hits the repo i'll rebase and reup. ? though should the installation of the quantum client be dependant on the `quantum` in ENABLED_SERVICES like I have it or only installed on the `q-svc` host?"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-01-25 23:56:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Jason, unless some OpenStack component needs it when Quantum (service) isn't installed, I would leave the client install under q-svc; for example in a multi-node install will some nodes need just the client?"}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-01-26 00:05:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Well it doesn't need it now but presumably you would only need the quantum client on the host that is running horizon, but not on the host running the nova-network service. I'll leave it as is in the other merge for now, since I don't use horizon or multi-node someone else can make that call ;)."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-01-26 00:11:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Allow for auditing of API calls.

Splits Resource.__call__() into two parts to allow for easy auditing
of the API stack--checking execution times, etc.  No behavior change
or execution time impact should be expected.

Change-Id: If9629e8b85f490c66499c42d6f6977a09d641c22

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 167, 'name': 'Christian Berendt', 'email': 'berendt@osism.tech', 'username': 'berendt'}, {'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 236, 'name': 'Monsyne Dragon', 'email': 'mdragon@rackspace.com', 'username': 'mdragon'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 979, 'name': 'Dave Walker', 'email': 'email@daviey.com', 'username': 'davewalker'}, {'_account_id': 1812, 'name': 'p-draigbrady', 'email': 'P@draigBrady.com', 'username': 'p-draigbrady'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-01-27 21:44:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm a bit wary of adding this functionality by default into utilities. While this makes output somewhat nicer for humans, it's worse for scripts. It would be fairly easy to have a separate utility to pipe to that could align and optionally put borders around. I.E. maybe updating `column` with a few options would be more appropriate.

    # nova-manage service list | column -t
    Binary          Host                   Zone  Status   State  Updated_At
    nova-scheduler  localhost.localdomain  nova  enabled  :-)    2012-01-27  21:44:07
    nova-volume     localhost.localdomain  nova  enabled  :-)    2012-01-27  21:44:03
    nova-network    localhost.localdomain  nova  enabled  :-)    2012-01-27  21:44:03
    nova-compute    localhost.localdomain  nova  enabled  :-)    2012-01-27  21:44:03"}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-01-27 21:53:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I do think the removal of the hardcoded alignments is a good improvement though. I guess you could keep just that by adding the border=False param to pt.printt().'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-27 22:01:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It looks quite nice. I'm really hoping that we kill nova-manage during e-4 though :)"}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-01-27 22:40:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

line space issue"}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-01-27 22:41:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Minor nit"}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2012-01-27 22:49:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

it's nice to have some better formatting, however I would suggest having a commandline option to turn off formatting for a parsing friendly format."}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-28 14:57:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think it makes no sense to change anything in nova-manage if it's planned to remove nova-manage during the next weeks.

Vish, is there a confirmed bug report for the process of replacing nova-manage with something else with the result of removing nova-manage? I will then abandon this change request and will close this bug report as "won't fix". If there is no bug report yet I think it's a good idea to create one.

Also I will have a look for other bug reports and will close them as "won't fix", too.

The flag for disabling the formatting is a good idea, should be introduced in python-novaclient (if it's not available there).'}, {'account_id': 979, 'date': '2012-01-31 21:51:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For info, It was discussed in the weekly meeting, and nova-manage deprecation is no longer a target for essex.

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-31 22:18:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

But it's probably a target for Folsom. So I think it makes no sense to change anything in nova-manage and I'll abandon this change request."}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-31 22:18:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

nova-manage will probably be removed in Folsom'}]

commit_message:
introducing prettytable in nova-manage
rewrote the print statements of "service list" (as a first example, leftover has to be rewritten if you like the usage of prettytable)

regarding bug 922824

without prettytable (state of the art):

stack@devstack001:~$ nova-manage --flagfile nova/bin/nova.conf service list
Binary           Host                                 Zone             Status     State Updated_At
nova-compute     devstack001                          nova             enabled    :-)   2012-01-27 20:22:16
nova-cert        devstack001                          nova             enabled    :-)   2012-01-27 20:22:15
nova-volume      devstack001                          nova             enabled    :-)   2012-01-27 20:22:17
nova-network     devstack001                          nova             enabled    :-)   2012-01-27 20:22:19
nova-scheduler   devstack001                          nova             enabled    :-)   2012-01-27 20:22:10
nova-consoleauth devstack001                          nova             enabled    :-)   2012-01-27 20:22:12

with prettytable:

stack@devstack001:~$ nova-manage --flagfile nova/bin/nova.conf service list
+------------------+-------------+------+---------+-------+---------------------+
|      Binary      |     Host    | Zone |  Status | State |      Updated_At     |
+------------------+-------------+------+---------+-------+---------------------+
| nova-compute     | devstack001 | nova | enabled | :-)   | 2012-01-27 20:58:23 |
| nova-cert        | devstack001 | nova | enabled | :-)   | 2012-01-27 20:58:21 |
| nova-volume      | devstack001 | nova | enabled | :-)   | 2012-01-27 20:58:23 |
| nova-network     | devstack001 | nova | enabled | :-)   | 2012-01-27 20:58:25 |
| nova-scheduler   | devstack001 | nova | enabled | :-)   | 2012-01-27 20:58:17 |
| nova-consoleauth | devstack001 | nova | enabled | :-)   | 2012-01-27 20:58:18 |
+------------------+-------------+------+---------+-------+---------------------+

Change-Id: I248efc4aef6240df7144d9bb978a37818db2fce9

commit_message:
Remove utils.runthis().

Fixes bug 884825.  The bug was pointing out some unused variables
noticed by pylint.

utils.runthis() was only used in one place and doesn't really provide
much value over utils.execute(), so just remove it.

Change-Id: I3dcc34bd840a128418b58a8a66acb62adf3fc9cc

commit_message:
Add support for OS_* environment vars

Add the OS_* env variables to mirror the NOVA_* vars; example:
setting OS_USERNAME will override NOVA_USERNAME in the clients and
tools, but if left unset it defaults to NOVA_USERNAME.

Adds exercises/client-env.sh to test operation of command-line
clients with only the OS_* variables set

Addresses bug 897304, http://wiki.openstack.org/CLIAuth

Change-Id: I72450153541072fe8026a82748cfcd1cf5ed31d8

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-31 17:56:43.000000000', 'message': "Be more explicit about emptying connection pool.

This patch makes some code in test_qpid be more explicit about emptying
the connection pool.  It now ensures that it removes exactly how many
connections are in the pool.

The previous code made a couple of assumptions.  First, it assumed that
only one connection was in the pool (which is true, but it's still nice
not to make the assumption here in the cleanup code).  Second, it
assumed that free() returned the number of connections that have been
placed in the pool.  This is not correct.  The result also includes the
number of connections that could be created based on the max size of the
pool. Use the free_items attribute instead, which gives the exact number
of connections that have been put() in the pool.

Change-Id: I97378919c2d3e68f224862f07a75529575647163
"}]
commit_message:
Be more explicit about emptying connection pool.

This patch makes some code in test_qpid be more explicit about emptying
the connection pool.  It now ensures that it removes exactly how many
connections are in the pool.

The previous code made a couple of assumptions.  First, it assumed that
only one connection was in the pool (which is true, but it's still nice
not to make the assumption here in the cleanup code).  Second, it
assumed that free() returned the number of connections that have been
placed in the pool.  This is not correct.  The result also includes the
number of connections that could be created based on the max size of the
pool. Use the free_items attribute instead, which gives the exact number
of connections that have been put() in the pool.

Change-Id: I97378919c2d3e68f224862f07a75529575647163

commit_message:
fixes melange ipam lib

Melange can have multiple ip_blocks assigned to a network. However
the ipam lib assumes that each block is its own L2 network and assigns
ips from each ip_block for every instance.

From internal bug.

Change-Id: I72699f178cfeb214b2911200a7e9ed9b255252f1

messages:
[{'account_id': 112, 'date': '2012-01-30 22:35:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

What does this allow?  I see it lets you set the type from the servicecatalog but why?

bug / blueprint?"}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-01-31 16:18:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Here's the bug (wasn't entered at the time I submitted this): https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/924052

"If more than one service has the same region in a service catalog, novaclient may select the wrong endpoint.

To reproduce, point novaclient at an identity service that has multiple services with the same region name, and sometimes one will get selected and sometimes another will.

When looking for endpoints, novaclient should search for "compute" for the service type, in case more than one service type matches region."'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-01-31 17:42:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-01-31 17:57:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned'}]

    'http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AmazonEC2/dg/2007-01-03/ApiReference-SOAP-TerminateInstances.html'

Remove dead test_terminate_instances code in test_cloud.py

commit_message:
bug 924267: Explicitly set firewall_driver to nova.virt.libvirt.firewall.IptablesFirewallDriver

Because of https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/924266, the default firewall_driver should
not be the libvirt's one. So set the driver explicitly.

Change-Id: I1e6a0d824e857bb082eef2a684445241d4c31aae

I'm new to python and Django, so any advice on that welcomed!"}, {'account_id': 741, 'date': '2012-01-23 18:18:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 741, 'date': '2012-01-23 18:28:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-01-23 18:35:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Kiall - take a look at this UI that Paul Tashima from nebula put together: https://nebula.notableapp.com/posts/391efe1b94711ec4527b6f72a61e789b6a4a54b7

In that, you will see that he allows the user to explicitly choose between the cidr and group.  I think that will make this more usable, as it enforces your integrity logic at the ui layer.

As for your validation style question, what you did looks reasonable but I'll defer to Gabriel on that code style issue.

It looks like you need to run pep8 on your modified files to correct some white spacing.  Just do "pep8 [file] and it will complain till you fix all the issues"'}, {'account_id': 1710, 'date': '2012-01-23 21:49:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

This may also be accomplished with description text detailing the use of the source group and CIDR fields."}, {'account_id': 741, 'date': '2012-01-23 21:51:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Add support for same tenant source-group security rules. Fixes bug #860780.

 * Adds support for displaying source-group rules
 * Adds support for deleting source-group rules
 * Adds support for creating source-group rules

Form level validation errors are now displayed, but not 100% correctly.

Change-Id: I35131f7d24361384bd2b222de10b34eb94622f48

subject: Initial illumos support
messages:
[{'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-01-09 18:57:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This is very early support for illumos / OpenIndiana / OpenSolaris / Solaris with KVM; a lot of functionality isn't yet implemented.  The "basics" do work however (instance start / stop), so I thought it best to submit it early for discussion.

Some points of interest:

There's no libvirt, so it talks to KVM directly over the monitor socket
It uses SMF services to persist KVM instances.  The OS persists networking settings etc.
It uses ZFS for instance storage.
There are SMF services for nova-compute, nova-api etc; these seem to work just great on Solaris (although I had to bump the version of lxml), and the EC2 metadata service must be disabled

It's mostly self-contained in the illumos, so if it isn't specifically selected it shouldn't affect anything, so I propose that it's better to merge this even at this early stage and see if it attracts other contributors (or whether it's just me that's still loves this OS).'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-01-09 19:49:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-01-09 19:49:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Fixed pep8 violations.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-09 19:52:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Justin, could you work with monty and jim to figure out how we can get a version of this running in jenkins?  Be nice to ensure we don't break it."}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-01-09 19:54:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-17 08:18:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Ok, I've only taken a quick look over this and have high-level comments/questions:

- Not using libvirt makes me sad. I know a bunch of work has been done on libvirt for Solaris, so this seems like a fairly wasteful approach. Could you go into more detail about your choice?

- I'd have preferred to see a blueprint associated with this and prior discussion on the mailing list?

- How likely is it that this new driver will bitrot over time like the vmware and hyperv drivers? Your comment about attracting more contributors suggests there isn't a lot of interest in this even now? Isn't it much more likely that Illumos support would stay in good shape if it was based on libvirt?

- "illumos" probably isn't the best name for this. Firstly, is it really illumos you're using or smartos? Also, I'd hope that we would see libvirt-on-illumos support eventually, so maybe "sadok" for "Solaris And Directly Operated KVM". Yes, thank you, I know rule at naming things :-)

- The lxml version bump could be in a separate patch included before the illumos support

- Do we really need VIF driver support? There's only one driver, right?

- Like wise for the quoata logging change - seems totally unrelated to illumos

- There's a heap of commented out code that I'd like to see removed before merging

- The amount of copied code is worrying too - e.g. the VIF code is missing the recent "Add missing space between XML attributes" fix

- Should use nova.utils.read_cached_file() for reading the template

- We don't have init scripts, systemd units or upstart jobs in git, but maybe we should. So, I'd put the nova service SMF XML files in e.g. nova/dist/smf and we'd also have nova/dist/{rh-sysvinit,systemd,upstart}

- The glance SMF configs should be in glance. Likewise rabbitmq.xml doesn't belong in Nova

- kvm.xml and kvm-instance-smf are specific to the illumos driver, so should belong in there'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-01-24 06:02:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Doh - sorry about the delay!  I need to figure out how to turn on alerts!

> Not using libvirt makes me sad. I know a bunch of work has been done on libvirt for Solaris, so this seems like a fairly wasteful approach. Could you go into more detail about your choice?

I'm happy that you/others are working to get libvirt running on Solaris/Illumos.  I've been told it didn't support Zones, and any support for KVM would obviously be bleeding edge.  Some of the features that libvirt provides (instance management) are more naturally handled through SMF on Illumos.  I also didn't want to mess around with porting libvirt - I wanted to get OpenStack working!

I think, looking at the code, that it's much nicer by virtue of going direct to KVM, now that KVM has the nice JSON based interface.  What would adding libvirt get us here?

> I'd have preferred to see a blueprint associated with this and prior discussion on the mailing list?

There is an Approved blueprint, though it seems to have languished.  I'm more of a coder than a debater though; I much prefer the discussion here!  This was just a first code push for discussion (e.g. Vish's great comment that this could be driven through the test suite)

> How likely is it that this new driver will bitrot over time like the vmware and hyperv drivers? Your comment about attracting more contributors suggests there isn't a lot of interest in this even now? Isn't it much more likely that Illumos support would stay in good shape if it was based on libvirt?

I don't think libvirt can save VMWare or Microsoft/HyperV :-)  I personally find not having libvirt here to be a positive thing - it's one less layer in which bugs can hide.  But I think the virtue of open source is that you can get libvirt on Illumos support up to par and then we'll have two ways to support Illumos, just like there are two ways that Xen is supported.  When you add support for ZFS to the libvirt tree, you'll probably have easy support for btrfs as well.  Equally, the KVM driver can choose to make use of the Illumos QEMU monitor code.  Cross-pollination makes for a better OpenStack!


> "illumos" probably isn't the best name for this. Firstly, is it really illumos you're using or smartos? Also, I'd hope that we would see libvirt-on-illumos support eventually, so maybe "sadok" for "Solaris And Directly Operated KVM". Yes, thank you, I know rule at naming things :-)

It relies on features that are present in the Illumos kernel: KVM, CrossBow, ZFS etc.  It actually uses the OpenSolaris/OpenIndiana userland, so it's really OpenIndiana.  However, it's a fairly easy matter to tweak the commands used for the different userlands (SmartOS, Nexenta etc)  The common feature is that it relies on OS features that are provided by Illumos.

> The lxml version bump could be in a separate patch included before the illumos support

Fair enough!

> Do we really need VIF driver support? There's only one driver, right?

I'll check this out in more detail.  However, I think keeping it modular is probably important to easily support other networking implementations, even if there's only one networking implementation at the moment, particularly when there's a pre-built approach to doing so.

> Like wise for the quoata logging change - seems totally unrelated to illumos

Yes.  I'll clean that up.

> There's a heap of commented out code that I'd like to see removed before merging

Agreed!  I'll clean that up too!

> The amount of copied code is worrying too - e.g. the VIF code is missing the recent "Add missing space between XML attributes" fix

I'll check out that fix.  I think you have to start with a copy and paste, because there's no other definition of the contract (?).  I've been working on Vish's suggestion of getting the test suite up and running as a way of moving this forwards.

> Should use nova.utils.read_cached_file() for reading the template

Thanks for the pointer!

> We don't have init scripts, systemd units or upstart jobs in git, but maybe we should. So, I'd put the nova service SMF XML files in e.g. nova/dist/smf and we'd also have nova/dist/{rh-sysvinit,systemd,upstart}

Yes, this is a bit messy at the moment, and I don't really think these are worthy of a top-level folder.  I like the dist suggestion!

> The glance SMF configs should be in glance. Likewise rabbitmq.xml doesn't belong in Nova

Agreed on both counts.

> kvm.xml and kvm-instance-smf are specific to the illumos driver, so should belong in there

In dist - I agree.  I think I'm going to rename these to nova-kvm or something similar; they're actually quite specific to nova's utilization and I think it would be better if users didn't manually create their own instances.  It's quite nice that SMF offers us a sort of namespacing here for keeping things separated.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-31 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-31 06:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

subject: Modify HACKING to limit decorator usage.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 34, 'name': 'Todd Willey', 'email': 'todd@ansolabs.com', 'username': 'xtoddx'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 616, 'name': 'Mark Washenberger', 'email': 'mark.washenberger@markwash.net', 'username': 'markwash'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 998, 'name': 'Naveed Massjouni', 'email': 'naveedm9@gmail.com', 'username': 'ironcamel'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-01-11 16:55:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

I'm ok with the general rule to limit decorator usage to two.

It would be nice to have some proposed examples of how to cleanup some overuse of decorators in a way that follows this proposed change.

I don't know if that's appropriate for HACKING or somewhere else, but it's likely just stating not to do it won't make much of a difference unless we can show examples of how to cleanup existing usage."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-01-11 18:09:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-01-11 18:47:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I still think we need some example cleanups, but that's probably not appropriate for HACKING"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-01-11 18:48:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Sorry, working on some examples right now, just wanted to go ahead and get in the whitespace fix.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-01-11 21:01:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> It would be nice to have some proposed examples of how to 
> cleanup some overuse of decorators in a way that follows
> this proposed change.

Sure. I hinted at this somewhat in the commit message but I think it serves well to look at some examples. 

One way to refactor the decorator usage is to enrich the calling context. For example, in nova/compute/manager.py, we use exception.wrap_exception 46 times--about once for every public method on the compute manager. Now, it is certainly better to have those 46 lines than to duplicate 46 * 5 or so lines that would be required to add that functionality explicitly to each method. But, I'd wager we could reduce the 46 down to O(1) if instead of modifying the methods with decorators, we changed the calling context of manager. AFAIK, there is only one calling context for compute/manager, and that is nova.rpc.impl_kombu.ProxyCallback:__call__. If we even just make the notifier attribute of the manager substitutible, we could do something like

notifier = getattr(self.proxy, 'notifier', None)
try:
   node_func(context=ctxt, **node_args)
catch Exception, e:
   if notifier:
       notifier.notify(e)
   # ... other wrap_exception logic
   raise

(Okay, maybe also need to worry about impl_carrot, but rpc could be/ought to be refactored to put the callback logic in just one place since it has no dependency on the transport details. It only depends on message body format which can be the same across transport implementations).

Sometimes we use decorators to address cross-cutting concerns. For example, in nova/compute/api.py, there is the decorator checks_instance_state, which addresses the concern of instance vm_state and task_state preconditions. This is a situation where I can easily see compute api methods growing into command objects, with duplication minimized using inheritance and template methods.

class ComputeCommand(object):

    def _check_instance_state(context, instance):
        return True

    def _process(context, instance, *args, **kwargs):
        raise NotImplemented

    def process(context, instance, *args, **kwargs):
        if not self._check_instance_state(context, instance):
            raise Conflict
        return self._process(context, instance, *args, **kwargs)

This refactoring is not clearly advantageous for the present demands on the compute api. However, it is much nicer to work with when we try to add policy checks or synchronization, both of which have (or had) recent merge props that extended the use of decorators. For example, we could add _enforce_policy() to the ComputeCommand and call it in process(). Similarly, if we chose to add per-instance synchronization, we could add lock management directly to process() without the need for decorators.

I realize these examples are a bit hazy, and I'm asking you to use your imagination to fill them out. It is my hope that by putting a rule like this in HACKING, reviewers and submitters can work together to find a sensible refactoring for any change that comes in to add a third decorator to function or method."}, {'account_id': 34, 'date': '2012-01-13 13:36:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I don't want to +2/approve this without more buy-in, but I think the goal of having less than 2 decorators is great.

This change is mentioned here, FYI: https://review.openstack.org/#patch,sidebyside,3002,2,nova/api/openstack/v2/servers.py"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-13 16:12:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

There are cases where, I think, decorators enhance the explicitness of the code—for instance, @wsgi.serializers(), @wsgi.deserializers(), and @wsgi.response() in my recently committed serializers patch and @wsgi.action() and @wsgi.extends() in my pending patch <https://review.openstack.org/#change,3002>.  In these cases, its more difficult to limit the number of decorators: there are methods that need 4 out of the 5 to fully express their requirements.  I'll also note that these decorators are pretty simple, since they only set function attributes; but that also means they need to be above decorators that wrap functions."}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-13 23:03:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Limiting the number of decorators to 2 seems arbitrary and too heavy handed, in my opinion. What would be more useful to me is if you provided guidelines on the proper use cases for decorators instead.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-13 23:11:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

+1 to Naveed.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-01-14 21:41:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Kevin,

I agree that in your changes you have used decorators very expressively. But I doubt any of us is saying that there are no similarly expressive or explicit alternatives to using decorators.

My motivation in suggesting this change is the frustration I've had in trying to maintain and extend code that extensively uses decorators. Often decorators make a given task straightforward--so long as that task is consistent with coding in a statically-composed global-scope approach. My experience is that often tasks that start out compatible with static/global coding don't stay that way as we find new requirements and new ways to extend them. Or, we have to bend over backwards to avoid breaking the static/global constraint. Because of this experience, every time I see decorators used for something other than the very base case (i.e. memoization, trace logging) I see code that is less resilient to change."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-01-14 22:06:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Naveed,

As far as proper use cases, I would prefer to only see decorators that do not mess with the conceptual interface of a function. That is, the decorated function should be substitutable for the original. For example, memoize or a decorator that does trace logging. 

I was initially afraid that this definition would be heavyhanded--more so than saying "no more than 2 decorators." But now I wonder, would this restriction be more acceptable to you? 

I would ask you the same question, Kevin. After looking more carefully at your wsgi stuff, it seems that since you are only modifying function attributes that are used in the calling context, it seems your use of decorators would be compatible with this rule. It's a bit of a gray area if the calling context would throw an exception if any one of your decorators is missing--but that's not the case, is it?'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-15 05:42:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Mark, I am assuming that "do not mess with the conceptual interface of a function" means "do not change the signature of a function." I like that much better than your original language.  That seems very sensible to me.  Just out of curiosity, can you point to an example in our code base of a decorator that violates this rule?'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-01-15 16:02:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Naveed,

I think I was a bit unclear. I am thinking of a stronger restriction.

If a decorator changes the meaning of an argument or the return value, it would violate this rule. For (a fake) example,

def in_json(fun):
    def wrapper(request):
        request = json.loads(request)
        return json.dumps(fun(request))
    return wrapper

@in_json
def do_something(request):
    ...

This violates the rule because the decorated function (which takes and returns json) is not substitutible with the original (which takes and returns dicts, lists, strings, or ints).

Another example that would violate this rule is a decorator that enforces rules before passing off to the wrapped function:

def protect(fun):
    def wrapper(foo, bar):
        if foo == 10:
            raise Exception
        return fun(foo, bar)
    return wrapper

@protect
def somefunction(foo, bar):
    return foo + bar **2

This example violates the rule because it changes the conceptual interface. Undecorated, somefunction(10, 2) returns 14. But decorated, it raises an exception. Interpreting the rule this way would mean that you also cannot catch and hide or transform and exception in a wrapper function.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-16 16:23:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yeah, my accesses to function attributes are done carefully to avoid exceptions if the attributes are not present; since there are reasonable defaults for serialization, deserialization, and response codes, this is the right thing to do.  I'll also point out that my @wsgi.action() and @wsgi.extends() are a little more complicated, in that they interact with a metaclass to generate a dictionary of actions and extensions…but again, no exceptions thrown in the calling context due to presence or absence of the decorators, just some more metadata used to pick the right methods to call.

All that to say, your proposal to not "mess with the conceptual interface of a function"—which of course needs a better description in the documentation :)—is more acceptable to me.  (Maybe a hybrid: only allow 1 of those kinds of decorators, closest to the function definition?  My decorators need to be the outer-most decorators used…)'}, {'account_id': 998, 'date': '2012-01-16 16:42:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Mark, thanks for the clarification.  The restriction described by your first example seems very sensible to me.  I do not like your second example though.  It precludes the use of decorators for validating input arguments, which I think is a prefectly fine use of decorators. I don't see validation as a violation of the function interface. May I suggest we start with less strict language first, and strengthen it in the future if necessary."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-31 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-01-31 06:03:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]

[{'created': '2012-01-11 16:41:38.000000000', 'message': 'Modify HACKING to limit decorator usage.

Decorators are useful, pythonic shortcuts to apply transformations to
functions. However, we have recently gone a bit too far in adding lots
of decorators to methods, when we should really be looking at ways to
either 1) enrich the calling context with the functionality we need or
2) explicitly transform our functions into the command objects we
desire.

I do not think decorators should go away, nor do I think they are
inherently bad. But their complexity and syntax does not scale as well
as other approaches and we need to acknowledge that in HACKING to
motivate future refactorings and the review process.

Change-Id: Ic83eef3ca0b76a86de9ee3d205fdf24e5c847504
'}, {'created': '2012-01-11 18:09:24.000000000', 'message': 'Modify HACKING to limit decorator usage.

Decorators are useful, pythonic shortcuts to apply transformations to
functions. However, we have recently gone a bit too far in adding lots
of decorators to methods, when we should really be looking at ways to
either 1) enrich the calling context with the functionality we need or

desire.

I do not think decorators should go away, nor do I think they are
inherently bad. But their complexity and syntax does not scale as well
as other approaches and we need to acknowledge that in HACKING to
motivate future refactorings and the review process.

Change-Id: Ic83eef3ca0b76a86de9ee3d205fdf24e5c847504
'}]
commit_message:
Modify HACKING to limit decorator usage.

Decorators are useful, pythonic shortcuts to apply transformations to
functions. However, we have recently gone a bit too far in adding lots
of decorators to methods, when we should really be looking at ways to
either 1) enrich the calling context with the functionality we need or
2) explicitly transform our functions into the command objects we
desire.

I do not think decorators should go away, nor do I think they are
inherently bad. But their complexity and syntax does not scale as well
as other approaches and we need to acknowledge that in HACKING to
motivate future refactorings and the review process.

Change-Id: Ic83eef3ca0b76a86de9ee3d205fdf24e5c847504

commit_message:
exercises: Multihost support for Glance client

floating_ips and volumes exercises both access Glance directly, but
assume it is running locally.  To better accomodate exercising a
multi-host cloud, specify glance host via GLANCE_HOST setting which
defaults to HOST_IP to maintain current single-node functionality.

Change-Id: Iad06044af031083afa477204d446ada5161ca521

commit_message:
Remove non-working --key_path argument on boot

We can't inject an authorized_keys file since we can't control
the permissions of the file. Fixes bug 897214.

Change-Id: I3263f0818e78ef048fdb35e858a22687dc46c381

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-30 21:22:03.000000000', 'message': 'Bugfix for lp901819

Move DB lookups out of the virt layer for bw usage.
Migrate to storing the mac address in the table.
Only lookup network label when sending usage events.
Attempt to use info_cache for label lookup before
    punting to rpc call.

Change-Id: Ibc9df4685f309ce4dc700a05585badfed51e4adf
'}]
commit_message:
Bugfix for lp901819

Move DB lookups out of the virt layer for bw usage.
Migrate to storing the mac address in the table.
Only lookup network label when sending usage events.
Attempt to use info_cache for label lookup before
    punting to rpc call.

Change-Id: Ibc9df4685f309ce4dc700a05585badfed51e4adf

commit_message:
Tenant user administration upgrades.

  * Converts tenant users to datatables. Fixes bug 922351.
  * Updates role-based adding/removing of users for Keystone master. Fixes bug 922391.
  * Corrects role addition during user creation. Fixes bug 922393.
  * Adds the ability to choose the role with which the user should be added to the tenant.

Depends on client updates in https://review.openstack.org/#change,3527

Change-Id: I4d85e41a278534d7266c6fc542c0f289a4bca0e3

commit_message:
Implementation of new Nova Volume driver for SolidFire ISCSI SAN

* Adds new SolidFire driver that subclasses nova.volume.san.SanISCSIDriver
* Adds unit tests for new driver
* Adds new exception subclasses in nova.exception
* Adds John Griffith to Authors
Implements solidfire-san-iscsidriver
Change-Id: I4dc7508ba08f5333cde74d4cfeaae3939c5d2b02

subject: Fix permissions when creating files/permissions.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2011-11-02 20:19:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I would instead go with a umask(0) just before the "while running[0]:" in swift/common/wsgi.py and a umask(0022) just after the "if pid == 0:".'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2011-11-02 20:22:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I would instead go with a umask(0) just before the "while running[0]:" in swift/common/wsgi.py and a umask(0022) just after the "if pid == 0:" and the remove the current umask set in drop_privileges.

Also, looks like the container updater could use the same treatment. umask(0) just before fork() and umask(0022) just after realizing it's a child (after the "else:" and before the "signal...".'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2011-11-07 16:09:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2011-11-07 16:34:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

One inline comment and the umask call in drop_privileges needs removal.'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2011-11-10 16:22:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2011-11-11 14:21:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

swift/container/updater.py is still setting the umask(0022) in the parent side of the fork instead of the child; unless I'm reading something incorrectly."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2011-11-16 14:09:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2011-11-16 17:03:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 995, 'date': '2011-11-16 19:07:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(3 inline comments)

Sorry about all the back and forth but I'm going with clayg on this.  I'd like to keep the umask in the drop_priv function and let the children inherit it."}, {'account_id': 995, 'date': '2011-11-16 19:24:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-01-19 17:07:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-01-19 17:09:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I kind of lost the thread of what's going on here but I think that's what clayg/david.g wanted.. I tested it and it create the directories the way it needs to be. Let me know what do you think."}, {'account_id': 1603, 'date': '2012-01-19 19:41:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks like it does what was asked.'}, {'account_id': 995, 'date': '2012-01-24 22:24:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

looks good to me'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-01-30 19:37:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-30 19:38:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-unittests/119392/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-merge/66/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-30 19:38:21.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Remove fetching of networks that weren't created via nova-manage

For bug 922319: we want to make sure we only return networks created by
nova-manage and not any arbitrary network that Quantum could have for a given
tenant.

Change-Id: Icd4a9c00d0ed4faf5e404060e8b7a658d9b83257

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-27 05:24:54.000000000', 'message': "Remove session arguments from db.api

Possibly through copy-paste errors, some sqlalchemy session keyword args
made it into the db api. Some aren't even passed in to the IMPL's
equivalent function, and a db.api client has no sensible way of creating
such a session to pass in. Therefore this patch removes them.

Change-Id: I75237b542bdf4f75c1a07ae38bf485e0ff080339
"}]
commit_message:
Remove session arguments from db.api

Possibly through copy-paste errors, some sqlalchemy session keyword args
made it into the db api. Some aren't even passed in to the IMPL's
equivalent function, and a db.api client has no sensible way of creating
such a session to pass in. Therefore this patch removes them.

Change-Id: I75237b542bdf4f75c1a07ae38bf485e0ff080339

commit_message:
Refactor away the flags.DEFINE_* helpers

The next obvious step in porting to cfg is to define all options using
cfg schemas directly rather than using the flags.DEFINE_* helpers.

This is a large change, but it is almost entirely pure refactoring and
does not result in any functional changes.

The only change to note is that the default values for glance_host,
glance_api_servers and default_publisher_id options are now using opt
value interpolation i.e.

 -glance_host=_get_my_ip()
 +glance_host='$my_ip'

 -glance_api_servers=['%s:%d' % (FLAGS.glance_host, FLAGS.glance_port)]
 +glance_api_servers=['$glance_host:$glance_port']

 -default_publisher_id=FLAGS.host
 +default_publisher_id='$host'

Also note that the lower_bound check on the {report,periodic}_interval
options are no more, but this has been true since cfg was first added.

Change-Id: Ia58c8f0aaf61628bb55b1b8485118a2a9852ed17

subject: Allow to override SysLogHandler /dev/log for builds.
messages:
[{'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-01-24 21:48:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I am fine with the changes to the code. They pass all tests, don't seem to affect anything negatively, and include defaults that work with existing clusters.

However, I prefer that swift not include tools in its source tree that are for particular build environments or particular VCS or particular anything. (You'll notice there is an in-review patch to remove the tools/rfc.sh script.) Is it necessary for swift to include the wrapper shell script? Unless others think it's particularly useful to a general audience, I'd prefer that the script be removed from this patch.

However, if the script is to be included, I think it needs support for -h/--help usage options."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-01-24 22:02:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm fine with this change. Pretty simple, non-intrusive, might be useful to others but if not, it won't really bother anyone.

Might make a quick blurb about it in docs though."}, {'account_id': 1603, 'date': '2012-01-24 22:17:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm neutral either, but if it stay's there probably should be a quick blurb in the docs somewhere."}, {'account_id': 2400, 'date': '2012-01-30 14:01:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Resubmitted as I9ec3c04620a046e1838b36e291265389e9b5b888, adding a docstring and removing the shell script.'}]

Added fake-syslog-wrapper.sh for encapsulation of the mock, using

Change-Id: Idc1adb3b4c9619bff89b445d30f7dd2387474777

commit_message:
Allow to override SysLogHandler /dev/log for builds.

For example in openSUSE's Open Build Service we build as non-root in
a chroot where /dev/log does not exist.

Added fake-syslog-wrapper.sh for encapsulation of the mock, using
socat.

Also exit test scripts on failure, report the exit code.

Change-Id: Idc1adb3b4c9619bff89b445d30f7dd2387474777

subject: change the return code of "duplicate exceptions" from 500 to 409 in the fault wrapper of the WSGI middleware.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 167, 'name': 'Christian Berendt', 'email': 'berendt@osism.tech', 'username': 'berendt'}, {'_account_id': 191, 'name': 'Trey Morris', 'email': 'trey.morris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'tr3buchet'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-01-26 23:14:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

The code originally did that, but then it would leak sensitive information. See https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/868360 and https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/874472

I think the bug here is that a 500 error is being returned not that it's returning an opaque message."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-26 23:16:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Do not submit

(1 inline comment)

See also my in-line comment.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-26 23:20:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I don't think this is the proper fix.  We don't want to be exposing data from 500 errors to users.  500 means a server failure.  I think the proper fix to this would be to catch the already exists exception in the extension and add a proper HTTP error message with a description and a more meaningful error code like 409 is the right way to go here:

http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec10.html#sec10.4.10

If you can find a general place to catch all exception.Duplicate and turn them into 409s that might be useful, but we definitely don't want to be printing internal error text."}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-27 12:03:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-27 12:07:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Tried changing it to a more general way to change the http return codes in dependence of the type of the exception. like suggested the http return code for duplicates should be 409.

I'm not sure about the moved logging and return out of the try-except-block. I did this because the method normally returns in the try part and so I think we don't have to duplicate the logging and return code for each except block."}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-27 12:12:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sorry, the in-line comment written by johannes was not there before submitting this change request. I can follow your explanatory notes and submitted a new patch set.'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-27 12:15:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-27 12:16:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Sorry, forgot to remove one return statement in one of the except blocks.'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-27 13:40:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-27 13:42:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Sorry, missing import statement.

I made my last commits with bzr using my own development environment and I need some time to get used to work with devstack and git.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-27 16:16:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

This is still not the right place to put this.  You should put the fix in the specific method(s) of the keypair extension, rather than in the generic FaultWrapper, in my opinion.'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-27 17:26:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Kevin, why not using the general fault wrapper for the handling of exceptions of API calls? The error code 409 should be set for all duplicate exceptions and not only if a keypair is duplicate.

Also the exception send to the client is overwritten in the general fault wrapper to code 500 for all exceptions. So putting code into specific methods is no option, because the throwed exceptions will be overwritten by the general fault wrapper.

So I think it's a good way to catch exceptions of a specific type (for example Duplicate) and set exc to the correct webob exception or to 500 (if no specific exception is specified)."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-01-27 17:38:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I think the theory is that FaultWrapper is optional. The presence of it shouldn't affect the correctness of the result returned to the client. Your most recent change makes it required.

It's merely there to convert unhandled exceptions into something nice for the client to use. Ideally, there should be no unhandled exceptions reaching this layer."}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-27 17:57:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Is it a problem that't the fault wrapper is required?

At the moment the error codes send to the clients are wrong and this is (my point of view) a problem for customers using  the nova CLI.

The thrown exception KeyPairExists is correct, the key pair exists. I don't think that there is missing exception handling in the code for this specific exception.

The client has to receive some kind of error code, because the operation to add a new keypair can't be completed because the keypair already exists.

But this is not an internal server error, it's an conflict.

If I receive the code 500 (as customer) I'll contact my support team, If I receive some other error I know that probably I made something wrong. I don't want to receive a lot of support tickets for useless 500 errors.

I still think the the fault wrapper is the right place for dispatching catched exceptions and to decide there the correct error code."}, {'account_id': 191, 'date': '2012-01-27 23:41:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Do not submit

agree with kevin'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-01-27 23:55:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'll just refer to http://dirtsimple.org/2007/02/wsgi-middleware-considered-harmful.html for a more detailed explanation of why middleware shouldn't be required for correct behavior.

That isn't to say that Nova is perfect in this regard, but I'd rather not make this worse."}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-28 14:59:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Abandoned

I think the overall opinion is to not change the behavior in the fault wrapper, so I'll abandon this change and leave the bug report open."}]

commit_message:
change the return code of "duplicate exceptions" from 500 to 409 in the fault wrapper of the WSGI middleware.

don't change the explanation of the webob exception, it could contain sensitive information.

at the moment the error code for trying to add a existing code is 500:

stack@devstack001:~$ nova keypair-add foobar
The server has either erred or is incapable of performing the requested operation. (HTTP 500)

but should be 409:

stack@devstack001:~$ nova keypair-add foobar
There was a conflict when trying to complete your request. (HTTP 409)

Change-Id: Id0e681da991afcfcf306a490cddf605824c6f5ab

commit_message:
Fixes bug #919390 - Block Migration fails when keystone is un use.

I've Updated the calls to nova.virt.libvirt.utils.fetch_image() to match the rest of the class.

Additionally, nova.virt.images.fetch() currently makes no use of the user/project id supplied.

Change-Id: I2db4b8c1b6542909fcc2b452fc961e22fe2557bf

commit_message:
Removes unmainted requirements from setup.py

Horizon maintains a requirements list in tools/pip-requires.
This patch removes the unmaintained and incomplete list from
setup.py, to avoid misleading naive users.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-27 20:30:16.000000000', 'message': 'Add the Mapping interface to cfg.ConfigOpts

Implements blueprint cfg-mapping interface

With cfg, option values are accessed via attributes on ConfigOpts
objects e.g.

  conf = ConfigOpts()
  conf.register_opt(StrOpt('foo'))
  conf()
  print conf.foo

One use case that isn't easily supported with option values represented
this way is iterating over all the registered options. Standard
interfaces for listing attributes on an object aren't suitable because
they will list more than just the options.

For this use case alone, it's worth having ConfigOpts implement the
mapping interface. That way we can do e.g.

  for opt, value in conf.items():
      print "Option %s = %s" % (opt, value)

It's interesting to compare argparse's approach to this problem - option
values are attributes on a Namespace object which has no attributes or
methods to pollute the namespace of option names. This is a nice
approach, but would mean that we would be passing around both a
ConfigOpts object and a Namespace object. That's a bit too much overhead,
and the mapping interface provides a usable workaround where there is a
conflict.

Change-Id: Ic113919a20291048f962999229c76884ebdd5ad8
'}]
commit_message:
Add the Mapping interface to cfg.ConfigOpts

Implements blueprint cfg-mapping interface

With cfg, option values are accessed via attributes on ConfigOpts
objects e.g.

  conf = ConfigOpts()
  conf.register_opt(StrOpt('foo'))
  conf()
  print conf.foo

One use case that isn't easily supported with option values represented
this way is iterating over all the registered options. Standard
interfaces for listing attributes on an object aren't suitable because
they will list more than just the options.

For this use case alone, it's worth having ConfigOpts implement the
mapping interface. That way we can do e.g.

  for opt, value in conf.items():
      print "Option %s = %s" % (opt, value)

It's interesting to compare argparse's approach to this problem - option
values are attributes on a Namespace object which has no attributes or
methods to pollute the namespace of option names. This is a nice
approach, but would mean that we would be passing around both a
ConfigOpts object and a Namespace object. That's a bit too much overhead,
and the mapping interface provides a usable workaround where there is a
conflict.

Change-Id: Ic113919a20291048f962999229c76884ebdd5ad8
