commit_message:
Separate time overrides from test machinery.

This patch separates the ability to override time (for testing
purposes) from the actual import of the test machinery. Horizon
should never import test modules and libraries like mox or
django.test.client unless tests are being run. Fixes 921943.

Change-Id: I7638b0fdb51926acbd809f33a9c35443ce069713

Change-Id: I05792755c9293e4dd80d642cb8eef6b0adda2ed4

commit_message:
Ignore case in policy role checks.

Update the default policy brain so that role checks ignore case.
Fixes an issue where roles in keystone didn't exactly match the
case of the role as specified in policy.json.

Fixes LP Bug #922660.

Change-Id: I05792755c9293e4dd80d642cb8eef6b0adda2ed4

commit_message:
Bugfix for lp901819

Move DB lookups out of the virt layer for bw usage.
Migrate to storing the network_uuid in the table.
Only lookup network label when sending usage events.
Attempt to use info_cache for label lookup before
    punting to rpc call.

Change-Id: I66e771ff2f03b25ac067c40f30754d0b4c98692b

commit_message:
Re-factor update.py to avoid breaking tests

nosetests tries to import update.py and fails.

Re-factor the code so that we have a main function that doesn't get
executed on import.

Note: setup.py would break nose similarly, except nose ignores setup.py
by default.

Change-Id: I609019d492f6fc2d7f2e8b6165228f879cf1ddb7

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-27 06:03:02.000000000', 'message': 'plugin/ovsplugin: teach ofp controller to ovs plugins

This patch implements blueprint:
Integrate OVS pluging exntension that allows multiple driver
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/quantum/+spec/ovs-driver-extension

This patch enhances ovs plugin for generic OVS controller support and
add Ryu NOS support.

This patch is to add ofp controller support to OVS.
Store ofp controller address in ovs quantum data base.
- ovs plugin: plugin_driver configuration
- ovs agent: agent_driver configuration
- nova firewall_driver
- nova linuxnet_interface_driver

There may be ports unmanaged by nova/quantum. Those ports are used
to connect vm to outside of physical machine. They needs special care.

Change-Id: I17801a7a74d4087838a8a26c1b1f97f28c2dcef3
'}, {'created': '2012-01-27 06:03:02.000000000', 'message': 'plugin/ovsplugin: teach ofp controller to ovs plugins

This patch implements blueprint:
Integrate OVS pluging exntension that allows multiple driver
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/quantum/+spec/ovs-driver-extension

This patch enhances ovs plugin for generic OVS controller support and
add Ryu NOS support.

This patch is to add ofp controller support to OVS.
Store ofp controller address in ovs quantum data base.
- ovs plugin: plugin_driver configuration
- ovs agent: agent_driver configuration
- nova firewall_driver
- nova linuxnet_interface_driver

There may be ports unmanaged by nova/quantum. Those ports are used
to connect vm to outside of physical machine. They needs special care.

---
Changes:
- rebased to 9c5c2caef13fa58234987527ab6caff829a37050
- some clean ups

Change-Id: I17801a7a74d4087838a8a26c1b1f97f28c2dcef3
'}, {'created': '2012-01-27 06:03:02.000000000', 'message': 'plugin/ovsplugin: teach ofp controller to ovs plugins

This patch implements blueprint:
Integrate OVS pluging exntension that allows multiple driver
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/quantum/+spec/ovs-driver-extension

This patch enhances ovs plugin for generic OVS controller support and
add Ryu NOS support.

This patch is to add ofp controller support to OVS.
Store ofp controller address in ovs quantum data base.
- ovs plugin: plugin_driver configuration
- ovs agent: agent_driver configuration
- nova firewall_driver
- nova linuxnet_interface_driver

There may be ports unmanaged by nova/quantum. Those ports are used
to connect vm to outside of physical machine. They needs special care.

Change-Id: I17801a7a74d4087838a8a26c1b1f97f28c2dcef3
Signed-off-by: Isaku Yamahata <yamahata@valinux.co.jp>
'}]
commit_message:
plugin/ovsplugin: teach ofp controller to ovs plugins

This patch implements blueprint:
Integrate OVS pluging exntension that allows multiple driver
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/quantum/+spec/ovs-driver-extension

This patch enhances ovs plugin for generic OVS controller support and
add Ryu NOS support.

This patch is to add ofp controller support to OVS.
Store ofp controller address in ovs quantum data base.
- ovs plugin: plugin_driver configuration
- ovs agent: agent_driver configuration
- nova firewall_driver
- nova linuxnet_interface_driver

There may be ports unmanaged by nova/quantum. Those ports are used
to connect vm to outside of physical machine. They needs special care.

---
Changes:
- rebased to 9c5c2caef13fa58234987527ab6caff829a37050
- some clean ups

Change-Id: I17801a7a74d4087838a8a26c1b1f97f28c2dcef3

Add a note explaining why unhandled exceptions shouldn't be returned
to users.

For future developers so they don't re-introduce a bug by accident.

Change-Id: I24f03adcc795db6252be988c076043bb74026733

subject: uses the instance uuid in libvirt by introducing a new variable 'uuid' for the used template instead of using a random uuid in libvirt
messages:
[{'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-26 09:54:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Very useful'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-26 17:44:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is there a good way to test that the specified uuid is being used?'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-26 18:58:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sure. You can check the generated XML configuration (directly), check the uuid used for the generated KVM process or check the uuid for the generated object in libvirt. here are three examples:

stack@devstack001:~$ nova --user admin --password testing list
+--------------------------------------+------------+--------+------------------+
|                  ID                  |    Name    | Status |     Networks     |
+--------------------------------------+------------+--------+------------------+
| a258fb82-6915-4344-85e3-15cbca732307 | testing001 | ACTIVE | private=10.0.0.3 |
+--------------------------------------+------------+--------+------------------+

stack@devstack001:~$ cat ./nova/instances/instance-00000003/libvirt.xml
<domain type='qemu'>
    <uuid>a258fb82-6915-4344-85e3-15cbca732307</uuid>
    <name>instance-00000003</name>


stack@devstack001:~$ ps ax | grep a258fb82-6915-4344-85e3-15cbca732307
22256 ?        S      0:14 /usr/bin/qemu-system-x86_64 -S -M pc-0.14 -no-kvm -m 512 -smp 1,sockets=1,cores=1,threads=1 -name instance-00000003 -uuid a258fb82-6915-4344-85e3-15cbca732307 -nodefconfig [...]


stack@devstack001:~$ virsh dominfo instance-00000003
Id:             2
Name:           instance-00000003
UUID:           a258fb82-6915-4344-85e3-15cbca732307
OS Type:        hvm
State:          running
CPU(s):         1
CPU time:       13.5s
Max memory:     524288 kB
Used memory:    524288 kB
Persistent:     yes
Autostart:      disable
Security model: apparmor
Security DOI:   0
Security label: libvirt-a258fb82-6915-4344-85e3-15cbca732307 (enforcing)"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-26 20:07:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

What I'm asking of you is to put a test in nova.tests.test_libvirt :)"}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-26 20:15:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'll try it. Have not yet written test cases for OpenStack and have to first read the documentation. I'll commit the case tomorrow."}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-26 21:15:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-26 21:19:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I added the test case but I think I failed committing it to this change. There is now a new change to review: https://review.openstack.org/#change,3483, which depends on this change.

Is it the wrong way to do "git commit -a --amend; git review" like documented in the wiki to update an existing change?

Maybe somebody can enlighten me.'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-26 21:29:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-01-26 21:31:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

rebased and added the test case correctly to this change, abandoned change Ib7ce897b6ca5f34d4fbfb40dd829d06bd13b712f.

thanks to brian.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-26 21:36:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Excellent.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-26 22:45:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-26 22:56:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful

subject: Jays recommendations
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-01-23 16:48:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi John, you forgot to amend your original commit :)

No worries. just do this:

 git reset HEAD^
 git commit -a --amend
 git review

No need to change your original commit message ... just add a note on the code review page in Gerrit that you addressed my suggestions.

Cheers!

-jay"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-26 20:45:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Fixes bug 914418

This turns out not to actually be a case of using the wrong exchange, rather
it is that the exchange's 'durable' flag does not match the queue if FLAGS.durable is set to 'False'.

Change-Id: I69ac7e84ac02a72dd204fa3aa27e73637594f509

subject: blueprint host-aggregates: OSAPI/virt integration, via nova.compute.api
messages:
[{'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-01-19 17:55:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-01-19 18:20:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Armando,

The compute api is already a very large (I should say, bloated!) interface. Can you look at adding this functionality in another place? Say, nova.compute.aggregate could contain:

class API(object):

  def __init__(self, db, ..)
    ...

  def create(...)
    ...
 
  def get(..., aggregate_id, ...) 
    ...

  def list(...)
    ...

class Aggregate(object):

  def __init__(...)
      ...

  def update(self, ...)
      ...

  def update_metadata(self, ...)
      ...

  def add_host(self, ...)
      ...

  def remove_host(self, ...)
      ...

  def delete(self)
      ...

Also, just wondering aloud if the ids should be uuids as with instances. . . I see that is part of the previous commit but it is not too late to change, if others feel similarly.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-01-19 18:30:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Mark,

thanks for the input. 

> The compute api is already a very large (I should say, bloated!) interface. Can you look at adding this functionality in another place? Say, nova.compute.aggregate could contain:

Agreed...I'll split the API.

> Also, just wondering aloud if the ids should be uuids as with instances. . . I see that is part of the previous commit but it is not too late to change, if others feel similarly.

I thought about it, but I went with ids because I feel uuids are an overkill; (availability_zone/id) is more than enough to identify an aggregate, which is an admin concept not to be exposed to the tenant/user.

Unless you (or someone else) feel strongly about uuids, I would keep ids. Just because instances use uuids it does not mean that aggregates should do the same. They are different concepts, with different life cycles and different management paths.

Hope that make sense!
Thanks,
Armando"}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-01-19 18:56:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-01-19 21:48:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Looks better. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-24 22:39:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(4 inline comments)

Looking good, Armando. I've only got a few comments."}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-01-25 11:59:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-25 16:55:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks for adding those comments, Armando.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-01-25 16:56:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-01-25 17:19:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-25 20:06:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Once again!'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-26 18:28:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-26 19:02:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified

commit_message:
blueprint host-aggregates: OSAPI/virt integration, via nova.compute.api

This commit introduces the first cut of integration between the OSAPI
Admin extensions for host aggregates and the virt layer.

This is part of a series of commits that have started with change:

https://review.openstack.org/#change,3035

messages:
[{'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-01-18 10:28:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2012-01-19 16:23:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-01-23 12:36:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-25 00:15:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Do not submit

(4 inline comments)

Design-related comments inline.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-01-25 12:28:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-01-25 17:19:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-01-25 18:06:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Hi Brian, thanks for the review!

I have addressed your comments, latest thing to address is the change in AuthZ. You said:

'Authorization has recently changed for the admin api. I'll do a follow-up branch to address this extension in-particular'

I am happy to do it, however, do I understand it correctly that in order to provide admin-only access to the API I need the following:

- authorize = extensions.extension_authorizer('compute', 'aggregates') at the top of the aggregates.py file
- authorize(req.environ['nova.context']) on each Controller's method
- tweak the policy.js file to enforce a ["rule:admin_api"]

Thanks!
Armando'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-25 18:09:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Yep, that's all you need to do. Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-01-25 18:18:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

sweet, I'll get on with it then!"}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-01-25 18:42:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-25 19:19:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

If you're going to remove LazySerializationMiddleware, rather than leave it in for backwards compatibility, you also need to remove ExtensionMiddleware."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-26 17:24:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-26 17:25:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Kevin: Thanks. ExtensionsMiddleware is gone now too.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-01-26 17:31:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Brian:

In my opinion api-paste.ini isn't even close to backwards compatible between Diablo and Essex. Why leave in these empty classes and pretend we have backwards compatibility when we aren't even close?

commit_message:
Remove LazySerializationMiddleware.

Removes LazySerializationMiddleware and ExtensionMiddleware. They
are no longer in use.

Fixes LP Bug# 922152.

Change-Id: Icd0b54d474d807125f522965de0d89741b14cf2f

'}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2011-12-22 10:28:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2011-12-22 16:31:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(3 inline comments)

The big problem for me here is that I don't see how the describe_resources() change relates to this blueprint. Please submit it as a separate patch with a detailed explanation in the commit message.

Also, please update this commit message to reference the blueprint as bcwaldon requested"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-03 14:30:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Ok, there's been a bunch of offline email about this which helps clarify the describe_resources changes.

Firstly, describe_resources was added (by the author of this patch) to support the live_migration command by allowing the admin to check the memory available on a host before live migrating to that host. See http://docs.openstack.org/diablo/openstack-compute/admin/content/live-migration-usage.html

So, the question is - if we are to support live migration in the admin API, shouldn't we also support something similar to describe_resources?

(IMHO, given the current design, then yes - the admin cannot blindly choose a host to migrate to. However, in future we will obviously want to give the admin some more useful help here)

Another question is whether nova-manage should use the admin API rather than just talking directly to the DB. There seems to be agreement that, yes, nova-manage should go over the admin API.

This appears to be why this commit removes describe_resources from nova-manage and show_host_resources from the scheduler."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-01-03 14:35:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

This could be made much more clear by splitting the commit into 3 related commits:

  1) Add migrateLive admin actions API

  2) Add resource usage details to the hosts API

  3) Remove describe_resource and show_host_resources because

(1) and (2) is covered by the blueprint, but could use some more detailed information in the commit message.

I don't think (3) is covered by the blueprint and could certainly use a much more detailed commit message explaining e.g. why nova-manage no longer needs this functionality, why we don't care about backwards compatibility here and why "service update_resource" isn't also removed?'}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2012-01-05 17:34:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (3 inline comments)

Hello Mark, thank you for giving me a chance to explain!

> So, the question is - if we are to support live migration in the admin API, shouldn't we also support something similar to describe_resources?
> (IMHO, given the current design, then yes - the admin cannot blindly choose a host to migrate to. However, in future we will obviously want to give the admin some more useful help here)

This needs deep discussion.
In exisiting live migration, scheduer checks whether dest host has enough memory/disk to accept instance.Because without enough memory/disk, instance may abruptly shutdown. Therefore, I was thinking admin naturally needs UI to know which dest host has enough memory/disk.

But someone say admin shoud prepare system monitoring tools, then I am not pretty sure describe_resource is inevitable now. So I think 2 choices here - one is that, describe_resource is suppored as API together with live_migration until we can say it unnecessary. Another is deleting describe_resource not only this patch but also nova-manage.
Therefore, although I take the former in this patch, the latter may also be a choice.

> Another question is whether nova-manage should use the admin API rather than just talking directly to the DB. There seems to be agreement that, yes, nova-manage should go over the admin API.
> This appears to be why this commit removes describe_resources from nova-manage and show_host_resources from the scheduler.

Actually, my next patch is ready to novaclient that enables admins using live migration from remote host.
As such, I think live migration related functionality in nova-manage is no longer necessary.
And originally, an conclusion at the Bexar design summit was that 1st live migration should be implemented at nova-manage, and support API if 1st implementation looks OK.
So, I think exisiting implementation is temporary.
Please let me know if I am against any agreement.

> why we don't care about backwards compatibility here and why "service update_resource" isn't also removed?
now I am submitting 2 merge proposal.

1) https://review.openstack.org/#change,2315
2) https://review.openstack.org/#change,2416

I remove "service update_resource" in 1).
1) is to refactoring exisiting live migration. In detail, existing live migration checks
whether dest host has enough memory/disk to accept instance. "service update_resource" is removed in this patch.
Actually, I was thinking 1) is merged, then this patch. But 2 MPs goes at same time by accident, now.

Regarding to the backwards compatiblity, upcoming patch to novaclient still keeps same usage.'}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2012-01-18 09:02:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2012-01-18 09:24:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Based on Marc's comment, this patch doesn't delete existing live_migration() and describe_resource() in nova-manage (for backward compatibility)

Although I was thinking existing implementation of live migration-related feature in nova-manage was temporary implementation(based on design summit discussion), I realize there are some objection nowadays.
I will ask on this matter to ML again when I post a new patch to delete live migration related functions in nova-manage."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-18 16:18:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

See inline"}, {'account_id': 1075, 'date': '2012-01-19 11:21:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-19 16:55:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Novaclient for usage features.  Kill openstackx.

 * Fixes bug 848403
 * blueprint novaclient-migration
 * Fully removes openstackx
 * Needs https://review.openstack.org/3382 to work for non-admin users

Change-Id: I3e7fcf2f79a92c92c6c66ff0637ed874563496d6

Add lxml to pip-requires

Without this, I was getting:

  ...
  ImportError: No module named lxml
  ...
  ERROR: test_versions_index (melange.tests.unit.test_versions.TestVersionsController)

  Got: ImportError('No module named lxml',)
  ...
  ERROR: test_versions_index_for_xml (melange.tests.unit.test_versions.TestVersionsController)
  Got: ImportError('No module named lxml',)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-26 16:09:26.000000000', 'message': 'Import copies of the required openstack.common modules

The APIs melange is using are "incubating" in openstack-common. See:

  http://wiki.openstack.org/CommonLibrary#Incubation

A config file is included for openstack-common's copy-and-paste script
to make it easy to update the code e.g.

  $> git clone .../melange
  $> git clone .../openstack-common
  $> cd openstack-common
  $> python update.py ../melange/

Note: the copies of the openstack.common modules should never be directly
modified, instead you should always make the modifications in openstack-common
and copy them across using the script.

Change-Id: I0245e30e4b4a9a2214c4f8a291b7f2caa54ab97e
'}]
commit_message:
Import copies of the required openstack.common modules

The APIs melange is using are "incubating" in openstack-common. See:

  http://wiki.openstack.org/CommonLibrary#Incubation

A config file is included for openstack-common's copy-and-paste script
to make it easy to update the code e.g.

  $> git clone .../melange
  $> git clone .../openstack-common
  $> cd openstack-common
  $> python update.py ../melange/

Note: the copies of the openstack.common modules should never be directly
modified, instead you should always make the modifications in openstack-common
and copy them across using the script.

Change-Id: I0245e30e4b4a9a2214c4f8a291b7f2caa54ab97e

commit_message:
Don't pass filter_properites to managers

Fixes bug 921789

distributed_scheduler is trying to pass filter_properties to compute
manager but it's not serializable.. and we shouldn't pass it anyway.

Change-Id: I17ce04b71dfa3cef77a6883ce3cd6fede95a538a

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-26 06:23:08.000000000', 'message': "rootwrap: Fix KillFilter matching

The match() method in the KillFilter is a bit buggy. Since most/many
run through this logic in their way to being matched, it creates subtle
issues elsewhere, specifically during linux_net bridge creation.  This
fixes two issues.

1. userargs gets elements directly popped off of it.  If the KillFilter
does not match the command its checking, the later filter that does is missing
one argument.
2. Type error on pid when checking /proc, this was causing issues on instance
tear down / kill -HUP'ing dnsmasq.

Fixes bug 921784

Change-Id: I058ff2276e3154e8c1f6cc7077fa485db60e5827
"}]
commit_message:
rootwrap: Fix KillFilter matching

The match() method in the KillFilter is a bit buggy. Since most/many
run through this logic in their way to being matched, it creates subtle
issues elsewhere, specifically during linux_net bridge creation.  This
fixes two issues.

1. userargs gets elements directly popped off of it.  If the KillFilter
does not match the command its checking, the later filter that does is missing
one argument.
2. Type error on pid when checking /proc, this was causing issues on instance
tear down / kill -HUP'ing dnsmasq.

Fixes bug 921784

Change-Id: I058ff2276e3154e8c1f6cc7077fa485db60e5827

commit_message:
Fix authorization checks for simple_usage.show

 * Normal users shouls be allowed to query their own usage info
 * Fixes bug 921327
 * Address bcwaldon's comment about using a default {} in authorize
 * Remove is_admin references
 * Remove policy-related tests
 * Add back test_verify_show_cant_view_other_tenant, implemented with test policy
 * Add vish's fixes from trunk merge

Change-Id: Ib0ce46419b7aedad34de957bfe2e60b10c5af11c

commit_message:
fixed bug lp:885966

add a flag FLAGS.use_usb_tablet to libvirt.xml.template to solve
the problem in cases when the virtual and real mouse cursors are
not synchronized using vncviewer or through websocket to access
windows virtual machine.

Change-Id: Ia8285ee3bb962dc0382308cd22a938f86104e8aa

commit_message:
Fix authorization checks for simple_usage.show

 * Normal users shouls be allowed to query their own usage info
 * Fixes bug 921327
 * Address bcwaldon's comment about using a default {} in authorize
 * Remove is_admin references
 * Rebase and change expected auth failure response from 401 to 403
 * Remove policy-related tests
 * Add back test_verify_show_cant_view_other_tenant, implemented with test policy

Change-Id: Ib0ce46419b7aedad34de957bfe2e60b10c5af11c

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-26 01:10:20.000000000', 'message': "Ignore connection_type when no instances exist

In migration 74, we had required that the connection_type flag
be set. That's annoying for new deployments, so bypass this check
if there are no instances in the databse. Fixes bug 921294

Change-Id: I9b829e80ad7fa7ded3c7a471cb68c9b342d973bb
"}]
commit_message:
Ignore connection_type when no instances exist

In migration 74, we had required that the connection_type flag
be set. That's annoying for new deployments, so bypass this check
if there are no instances in the databse. Fixes bug 921294

Change-Id: I9b829e80ad7fa7ded3c7a471cb68c9b342d973bb

commit_message:
Fixes bug 921265 - i'nova-manage flavor create|list'

These problems were introduced in https://review.openstack.org/2918
* nova-manage needs the change from local_gb to root_gb/ephemeral_gb.
* fixes 'nova-manage flavor ...'
* fixes 'nova-manage service describe_resource ...'

Change-Id: I63040359a425aac3ef7a0a84e6834b1dfe3a8790

Fix bug 921715 - 'nova x509-create-cert' fails

The 'CN' value passed to openssl was too long, shorten it.

[{'created': '2012-01-25 19:56:42.000000000', 'message': "Don't pass filter_properites to managers

Fixes bug 921789

distributed_scheduler is trying to pass filter_properties to compute
manager but it's not serializable.. and we shouldn't pass it anyway.

Change-Id: I17ce04b71dfa3cef77a6883ce3cd6fede95a538a
"}]
commit_message:
Don't pass filter_properites to managers

Fixes bug 921789

distributed_scheduler is trying to pass filter_properties to compute
manager but it's not serializable.. and we shouldn't pass it anyway.

Change-Id: I17ce04b71dfa3cef77a6883ce3cd6fede95a538a

commit_message:
Allow euca-upload-bundle to work with devstack

 * modifies stack.sh to run nova-cert and nova-objectstore
 * adds exercises/bundle.sh to test for bundling
 * requires https://review.openstack.org/#change,3200

Change-Id: I850891948fbdfdf5890225f94df755e5dbc733d0

commit_message:
Ignore connection_type when no instances exist

In migration 74, we had required that the connection_type flag
be set. That's annoying for new deployments, so bypass this check
if there are no instances in the databse. Fixes bug 921294

Change-Id: I9b829e80ad7fa7ded3c7a471cb68c9b342d973bb

Hey dan, dean is doing some testing on this right now - we'll have an update soon"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-01-25 23:31:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I wasn't sure about removing the empty quantum module from horizon, but I can't get it to fail with quantum not installed.  That must have been fixed in Horizon?"}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-01-25 23:41:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Dean.  That's a good point.  I'm wondering if it wouldn't be cleaner to move all of that code under the "enable quantum in dashboard, if requested"  if-block.  

My guess is that horizon is fine with the openstack-dashboard/quantum directory being missing if Quantum is not enabled, but we're probably setting up a bum symlink if Quantum is not installed.  

Now that Quantum has a separate client lib, we're going to work with the Horizon folks to make this cleaner.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-26 00:27:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/879/ : SUCCESS

subject: Add HACKING compliance testing to run_test.sh
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 177, 'name': 'Alex Meade', 'email': 'mr.alex.meade@gmail.com', 'username': 'alex-meade'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1419, 'name': 'Mike Pittaro', 'email': 'mikeyp@LaHondaResearch.org', 'username': 'mikeyp-3'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-20 16:33:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(9 inline comments)

I see a lot of errors in your new tool: some stylistic, but I found at least one straight-out syntax error."}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-01-20 17:49:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(3 inline comments)

Echo'ing the same stuff Kevin found, plus a few other nits

To be honest, I like the idea, but at first glance, the code looks pretty inefficient. Some of it involves multiple passes through the same string to identify exactly what you're looking for. I realize that it's just part of the test suite, but that's already becoming prohibitively sluggish."}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-20 23:04:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

Thanks for the feedback I will make the relevant changes.  

As for the code being inefficient and slow, I agree completely.  This is a result of using the pep8.py framework,  which was used since it was the closest tool to the job.  I still think a slow tool is better then no tool.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-20 23:33:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

I agree that slower is better than nothing, and using the pep8 framework makes sense.  But, if we're using the pep8 framework, it might be better to integrate the HACKING-compliance check directly into the pep8.  (If you aren't doing so already; I can't see if run_tests.py actually calls this tool during normal test run.)  My basic thought is, try to not slow the test suite down any more than we have to.  It already takes nearly 10 minutes to run the whole thing, at least on my system!"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-21 02:16:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-21 02:18:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

More changes to come ...'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-23 17:09:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (5 inline comments)

Just keeping things on your horizon as you continue working on this patch.

BTW, you may want to consider setting -1 or -2 on your own patch until you're ready to finally submit…"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-23 19:48:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Working on patch set 3"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-23 23:06:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-23 23:19:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(6 inline comments)

Getting better…"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-23 23:47:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-24 00:06:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

I'm also pondering whether you should split the elif tree up, i.e.:

    if logical_line.startswith('import '):
        if […]
        elif […]
    elif logical_line.startswith('from '):
        if […]
        elif […]

Not a requirement, mind you, just a thought (and I'm sure others might disagree with me :)"}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-24 00:43:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

I like your idea of cleaning up the elif tree (and am fixing accordingly), as for the __import__ line,  see inline comment.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-24 00:51:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-01-24 01:13:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-01-24 16:02:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (2 inline comments)

commit_message:
Updating example glance paste config.

The glance config has gone through a number of changes since
the sample paste files were added to keystone:

- Add generic PasteDeploy app and filter factories

[https://github.com/openstack/glance/commit/ba44d1c3]

- Split out paste deployment config from the core glance
  *.conf files into corresponding *-paste.ini files

[https://github.com/openstack/glance/commit/14593a3b]
[https://github.com/openstack/glance/commit/5835b30c]

Updating samples to conform to latest version supported by glance.

Change-Id: I52bcdfd1760f6f844e0a44dabe3294886bb7aafd

commit_message:
fixes bug 921698 by specifying network_owner_tenant_id

In the interface create API, uses an additional tenant_id parameter in the
network params for specifying the network owner tenant separately from the
instance owning tenant.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-25 20:34:57.000000000', 'message': "rootwrap: Fix KillFilter matching

The match() method in the KillFilter is a bit buggy. Since most/many
run through this logic in their way to being matched, it creates subtle
issues elsewhere, specifically during linux_net bridge creation.  This
fixes two issues.

1. userargs gets elements directly popped off of it.  If the KillFilter
does not match the command its checking, the later filter that does is missing
one argument.
2. Type error on pid when checking /proc, this was causing issues on instance
tear down / kill -HUP'ing dnsmasq.

Fixes bug 921784

Change-Id: I058ff2276e3154e8c1f6cc7077fa485db60e5827
"}]
commit_message:
rootwrap: Fix KillFilter matching

The match() method in the KillFilter is a bit buggy. Since most/many
run through this logic in their way to being matched, it creates subtle
issues elsewhere, specifically during linux_net bridge creation.  This
fixes two issues.

1. userargs gets elements directly popped off of it.  If the KillFilter
does not match the command its checking, the later filter that does is missing
one argument.
2. Type error on pid when checking /proc, this was causing issues on instance
tear down / kill -HUP'ing dnsmasq.

Fixes bug 921784

Change-Id: I058ff2276e3154e8c1f6cc7077fa485db60e5827

commit_message:
Fixes bug 921265 - i'nova-manage flavor create|list'

These problems were introduced in https://review.openstack.org/2918
* nova-manage needs the change from local_gb to root_gb/ephemeral_gb.
* fixes 'nova-manage flavor ...'
* fixes 'nova-manage service describe_resource ...'

Change-Id: I63040359a425aac3ef7a0a84e6834b1dfe3a8790

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-25 17:53:43.000000000', 'message': 'Change xattr usage to be more broadly compatible.

This patch updates the xattr image cache driver to use methods that are
more broadly compatible.  The issue here is that there is more than one
xattr Python module out there.  Specifically, there are:

    https://github.com/xattr/xattr
    http://git.k1024.org/pyxattr.git/

The previous glance code expected an interface available in the first
version.  This patch changes the code to use an interface that is common
to both of these.

This makes all of the image cache tests working against the current pyxattr
package in Fedora.

Change-Id: I1fca66cfe914364c921408b676a06387d1de5c2a
'}]
commit_message:
Change xattr usage to be more broadly compatible.

This patch updates the xattr image cache driver to use methods that are
more broadly compatible.  The issue here is that there is more than one
xattr Python module out there.  Specifically, there are:

    https://github.com/xattr/xattr
    http://git.k1024.org/pyxattr.git/

The previous glance code expected an interface available in the first
version.  This patch changes the code to use an interface that is common
to both of these.

This makes all of the image cache tests working against the current pyxattr
package in Fedora.

Change-Id: I1fca66cfe914364c921408b676a06387d1de5c2a

commit_message:
Fix mixed usage of 's' and 'self'.

The first version of this patch fixed one misuse of 'self' when 's' was
expected.  There were some other uses of 'self' that I missed.  This
patch just changes these functions to use 'self' everywhere.

Change-Id: I66b74f00e5416e3e67eb60cf6c505f70134e6ddb

@bcwaldon

Libvirt is actually the only hypervisor implementation to use the block device mapping variable passed into "driver.spawn", and it's expecting a dictionary but getting a tuple.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-01-25 19:33:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Ok, I buy the fix, just curious why it would only affect libvirt. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-25 19:36:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

libvirt is the only thing that accesses 'bd_mapping', so it only affects it right now."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-01-25 19:36:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Approved

commit_message:
Updating example glance paste config.

The glance config has gone through a number of changes since
the sample paste files were added to keystone:

- Add generic PasteDeploy app and filter factories

[https://github.com/openstack/glance/commit/ba44d1c3]

- Split out paste deployment config from the core glance
  *.conf files into corresponding *-paste.ini files

[https://github.com/openstack/glance/commit/14593a3b]
[https://github.com/openstack/glance/commit/5835b30c]

Updating samples to conform to latest version supported by glance.

Change-Id: I52bcdfd1760f6f844e0a44dabe3294886bb7aafd

subject: Limits race condition in tests to midnight (bug 921634)
messages: [{'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-01-25 16:27:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned\n\nPrefer Ralf's solution"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-01-25 16:19:08.000000000', 'message': "Limits race condition in tests to midnight (bug 921634)

This patch doesn't completely avoid the race condition
(I'm not sure how to achieve that, and still validate
dates?); instead, a race condition can now only occur when
the tests are run at midnight at the date rolls over
between the time the test starts and finishes.

This slightly reduces the test coverage and isn't
particularly elegant!

Change-Id: I8f7355bda1a6d38f70ee91f26fbc6dbd44adf581
"}]
commit_message:
Limits race condition in tests to midnight (bug 921634)

This patch doesn't completely avoid the race condition
(I'm not sure how to achieve that, and still validate
dates?); instead, a race condition can now only occur when
the tests are run at midnight at the date rolls over
between the time the test starts and finishes.

This slightly reduces the test coverage and isn't
particularly elegant!

Change-Id: I8f7355bda1a6d38f70ee91f26fbc6dbd44adf581

  1. Provides dom0 IPtables driver to implement the Provider firewall rules.
  2. Existing libvirt code has been refactored to reduce the amount of duplicated code to a minimum
  3. The three provider apis in ec2/admin.py file are now fixed the following way:
    a.    remove_external_address_block returned 'OK' on removing blocks which didn't exist. This is now fixed.
    b.    block_external_addresses raised exception earlier on duplicate network blocks. Now the exception is logged and failed status message is returned.
    c.  all the three provider apis now logs for invalid and improper inputs and return uniform (a dictionary ) and proper status messages for all cases.

commit_message:
Blueprint xenapi-provider-firewall and Bug #915403.

  1. Provides dom0 IPtables driver to implement the Provider firewall rules.
  2. Existing libvirt code has been refactored to reduce the amount of duplicated code to a minimum
  3. The three provider apis in ec2/admin.py file are now fixed the following way:
    a.    remove_external_address_block returned 'OK' on removing blocks which didn't exist. This is now fixed.
    b.    block_external_addresses raised exception earlier on duplicate network blocks. Now the exception is logged and failed status message is returned.
    c.  all the three provider apis now logs for invalid and improper inputs and return uniform (a dictionary ) and proper status messages for all cases.
  4. appropriate unit tests added to cover the same

Change-Id: I27d83186f850423a6268947aed0c9a349d8f8d65

commit_message:
blueprint host-aggregates: maintenance operations to host OSAPI exts

This commit introduces sub for a host maintenance_mode option into
the osapi. It is required for the host aggregates work.

This is part of a series of commits that have started with change:
https://review.openstack.org/#change,3035

Change-Id: Ib462ef9ad6b641bf1083cc176dfba6645020ccec

subject: bp/api-filters This changeset implements filters for core Quantum API and provides unit tests
messages:
[{'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Note: this changeset for some reason is reverting the changes concernign renaming quantum-venv to venv.

Feel free to review, but a new patchset will be uploaded for fixing this.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (6 inline comments)

Hi Aaron, 

thanks for your review.
I completely agree on a deeper abstraction in the code in filters.py. After all I was aware the code was still far from perfect when I pushed it, but I needed feedback and I realize than 1 one of code is sometimes much better then 100 pages of spec and design documents!

As regards moving filters into the view builders, that's something I'm not very keen about - more details in the comment.
On the other hand, I agree that it might be the case to add a distinct method to the plugin interface for doing filtering, but we need to discuss this on the mailing list as well.

Thanks again, this is exactly the kind of feedback I was looking for."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

More comments from me!'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Dan's observation is unfortunately true.
I originally had a conditional switch around the get_all operations, which I dumbly removed.
There are three things we can do:
1) Abandon the patch, and retarget the blueprint to Folsom, as no API changes should go into Essex-4.
2) Do filtering in the API layer only for Essex.
3) Restore the ugly conditional switch around the get_all operations (pass the keyword argument only if the plugin support filtering)
4) Add, as suggested by Aaron, two methods for filtered get operations; we should ensure QuantumPluginBase does not require plugins to implement this method. If we go for this route, we can also remove the plugin_can_do_stuff methods, as the presence of the get_all_xxx_filtered methods will imply filter support.

My vote is for option 4, which is the one requiring more work (not a lot tough). Option 1 and 2 are the easiest ones. I'd hate going for option 3."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

>I personally would be fine just requiring the plugins have
>kwargs... I didn't mean my comment to be interpreted that 
>the approach was fundamentally wrong, just that we should 
>fix up the OVS plugin before submitting this patch.

For some reason I thought it was decided to not change the plugin interface at this stage of the release cycle.
Change in the plugin interface would be straightforward for the plugins in the source tree.

> I actually think the bigger question is how we indicate  
> whether a plugin will support a query (and what
> granularity that provides). One concern I have with the 
> "get_all_xxx_filtered" approach is that I believe it 
> implies that a plugin will either support all or none of 
> the queries for "port" or for "network". 

Agreed. Also the same problem will re-surface for response pagination (have a look at the bug/801227 changeset).

> As I mentioned in my review, I think it would be great if 
> for each GET request, the set of query fields was passed
> to the plugin, and the plugin could decide if it supports 
> that exact set of query params, or if it wants to rely on
> the "default" filtering implementation. I like this for 
> two reasons:

> 1) some plugins may be able to efficiently perform some
> queries for ports, but not others. This lets them be 
> efficient when they can be, but fall back on the shared 
> code of the default implementation when they are not.

> 2) in the future, we will probably identify more fields 
> over which we want to filter on, for example, a port. How 
> would a plugin indicate that it supports the old fields, 
> but not the new ones, for a port?

All reasonable points.

> I don't think this makes plugins more complex, unless they 
> want. They could always just implement the 
> query_is_supported() method by looking only at whether the 
> query is for a 'network' or 'port', in which case the 
> complexity is the same as the original code proposal. 
Thoughts?

Complexity in the plugins will increase only marginally. Also in the API layer that would not be a lot of added complexity.

I will push updated code over the weekend.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(I tried to quote Dan's comments - that was utterly unsuccessful)"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks for your comment. 
I think You have a good point when you say we should either do all filtering in the plugin or in the API, but not split it between the two.
On the other hand Dan also has a good point when he says that a plugin implementation should not be forced to implement all the filters specified by the API. 

This all seems to indicate that we should go back to the drawing board and give up on merging this branch for Essex-3. The code would not go to waste; on the contrary, it has been extremely useful to highlight issues which were not evident from the specification. As the latins used to say "in code veritas". I also think we can reasonably agree on an exception on the soft feature freeze and get this feature in for Essex-4.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (7 inline comments)

More comments inline'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (6 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-pep8/117/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-unittests/148/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/48/ : This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Looks good but I think we should document all of the things that you can filter for (or at least the common ones) somewhere.'}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (2 inline comments)

Just some comments for now.. I will spend more time looking at it in about 30 minutes.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Please note that Patch Set 4 and Patch Set 5 might both be considered for merging into trunk.

While patch set 4 returns a pair with the unused filters, patch set 5 leverages Dan's proposal concerning the fact that the filter themselves are passed by reference and therefore return a scalar rather than a vector type."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Edgar, I noticed that for UCS tests run_tests.py attempts to run only unit tests defined in the Cisco directory.

I ran 'standard' use case on it slightly tweaking the script (but reverting it before commit), and everything went better than expected."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (2 inline comments)

Rebased code coming soon.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-pep8/118/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-unittests/149/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/49/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Do not submit

(18 inline comments)

This is really valuable stuff.  I have a good number of comments, and one blocker in that I think putting this patch in without updating the get_all_* methods in plugins will break the plugins.  

Running the OVS units tests with the following command gives lots of failures: 

PLUGIN_DIR=quantum/plugins/openvswitch/ ./run_tests.sh -N'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I personally would be fine just requiring the plugins have kwargs... I didn't mean my comment to be interpreted that the approach was fundamentally wrong, just that we should fix up the OVS plugin before submitting this patch.  

I actually think the bigger question is how we indicate whether a plugin will support a query (and what granularity that provides).  One concern I have with the "get_all_xxx_filtered" approach is that I believe it implies that a plugin will either support all or none of the queries for "port" or for "network".  As I mentioned in my review, I think it would be great if for each GET request, the set of query fields was passed to the plugin, and the plugin could decide if it supports that exact set of query params, or if it wants to rely on the "default" filtering implementation.  I like this for two reasons: 

1) some plugins may be able to efficiently perform some queries for ports, but not others.  This lets them be efficient when they can be, but fall back on the shared code of the default implementation when they are not.  

2) in the future, we will probably identify more fields over which we want to filter on, for example, a port.  How would a plugin indicate that it supports the old fields, but not the new ones, for a port?  

I don't think this makes plugins more complex, unless they want.  They could always just implement the query_is_supported() method by looking only at whether the query is for a 'network' or 'port', in which case the complexity is the same as the original code proposal.  Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This looks good.  I prefer the latter diff, which uses kwargs along, rather than returning a pair.  I will hold off to approve to see if Salv has anything to add (he should be online some point soon).'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Approved

has two core reviews. pushing.  we can always make minor changes after milestone-proposed.'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Rebased from previous change-set that had been reviewed by multiple core devs.  No major changes.  Approving.'}, {'account_id': 704, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

No major concerns, now all plugins should implement the filters part.'}, {'account_id': 704, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Working on the review! Please, just give me some more time..'}, {'account_id': 704, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

I couldn't run all unit test for UCS because our testbed is running python2.6 instead of 2.7 (there are some deprecated libraries). However, It looks fine to me! I just added a short comment."}, {'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (2 inline comments)

More inline comments.'}, {'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(6 inline comments)

I have a few design comments that I'm not sure warrant holding up this patch, only some discussion. The part I'm worried about is the duplication in filters.py.

Otherwise good work!"}, {'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

It's good to hear there is a plan to push filtering into the plugin. Thank you for cleaning up the filters file, lgtm!"}, {'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm not a fan of having filtering split between the plugins and the api. We should pick one location or the other. This makes it much easier to say "these plugins support filtering, these other ones can only be used with small installs." We are going to end up with a mess if we make filtering optional in some places and then try to look for that filtering elsewhere. To make filtering as easy as possible on the plugin developers we can let them call into the filters module; but I think it should be left up the the plugin to handle the filtering.

If we go this route all of the "plugin_can_filter" logic goes away and both the api and the plugins become cleaner. It also handles the situation of a plugin not understanding new arguments. Either it passes the query params to the filters module, handles them itself, or ignores it.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-pep8/120/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-unittests/151/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/51/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-25 09:30:13.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Adds extension for retrieving certificates

 * Makes euca-upload/euca-register work again
 * Provides means for novarc to be generated
 * Fixes bug 903345
 * Implements blueprint x509-cert-crud

Change-Id: I0b2a42fe5436243da6925ba199936b49458d6f8c

commit_message:
Migrated 'enabled' int columns to bool for postgres (bug 885426)

Also included additional fixes for bp portable-identifiers
which were discovered by running existing tests against
postgres, per the bug referenced above.

Change-Id: I6c51bb817ec12df33866ff632f906d17c90c8d54

Looks OK, but why is this dependent on your other patch?'}, {'account_id': 706, 'date': '2011-12-27 20:14:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(4 inline comments)

Overall I don't love adding to the log line length but I see the need for this and the log format is configurable so it works for me.

Feel free to talk to me on IRC if you'd like (#openstack-dev on freenode, my nick is blamar) so we can get this and your dependent branch straightened out."}, {'account_id': 1633, 'date': '2011-12-28 12:51:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2011-12-28 16:07:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2011-12-28 18:28:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I'm not sure I buy this. Right now, most deployments just separate service logs by file. This patch is going to add a lot of unnecessary data to those setups. Is there a reason that solution won't work for you?"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-01-13 05:11:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I don't mind adding the name as a possible parameter for the log message, but I would prefer to have it off by default. https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-unittests/144/ : FAILURE'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-25 05:04:29.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}, {'account_id': 233, 'date': '2012-01-25 05:04:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 05:04:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I remember our goal is to split the server from the client. Exceptions.py defines types which are used by both, for instance NetworkNotFound, types which are used only on the server, such as AlreadyAttached, and types which are used only on the client, such as AlreadyAttachedClient.

I'm not sure about the reason behind this, Mark would probably be able to provide more details. It was my opinion that, if we are planning to split the repository than what has been defined for the client should stay with the client and vice versa for the server-side. 

I realize however that this goes probably beyond the scope of this changeset; in order to get it into Essex-3 we can probably just make sure exceptions.py stays in both repositories and then file bugs for tidying up things.

For more details I'm on IRC."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 05:04:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

My concern has been clarified.
Still, it is not really good that the server depends on exceptions defined in the client module; however we'd better fix this in a separate changeset."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 05:04:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Monty, 

it all looks pretty good, but we should probably be a little bit more careful in splitting quantum/common/exceptions.py, as it contains both server-side and client-side exceptions.

I think the way in which those exceptions are structured so far is a bit messy, as client and server exceptions extends the same objects, and also it seems some exceptions are used by both client and server.

Please let me know if you need any help with splitting exceptions.py"}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-01-25 05:04:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It looks like we are removing --with-tissue from setup.cfg, and adding tissue into pip-requires.

I'm not scoring this review as I don't have enough knowledge of Quantum packaging, but this looks a bit unusual."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-01-25 05:04:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I noticed that etc/quantum.conf (and etc/quantum.conf.test, and etc/quantum/plugins/cisco/quantum.conf.ciscoext) all still reference quantum.common.extensions. \xa0This prevents quantum-server from starting correctly when I run from source (but I would suspect in other scenarios as well)."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-01-25 05:04:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Salv, is your thinking just to split out the exceptions into two files, one for client, one for server?  I think that would make sense.  Any chance you can take a crack at this today (your time)?  I'm getting concerned, as I think this patch is probably the most critical for landing during E-3."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-01-25 05:04:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-01-25 05:04:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2170, 'date': '2012-01-25 05:04:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Dan may have mentioned this, but quantum.conf needs the following change:

# OLD line
# paste.filter_factory = quantum.common.extensions:plugin_aware_extension_middleware_factory

# NEW line
paste.filter_factory = quantum.extensions.extensions:plugin_aware_extension_middleware_factory

Otherwise, quantum won't start up.

I am also unable to get the quantum binary to execute after install on my clean devstack machine. pkg_resources is unable to import the cli module.

A README would also be useful."}, {'account_id': 2170, 'date': '2012-01-25 05:04:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

LGTM.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-01-25 05:04:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Build Successful

commit_message:
bp/api-error-codes
Restructured API error codes for Quantum API v1.1
This changeset provides the following changes:
- Only standard HTTP errors for Quantum API v1.1
- Customized fault response body formatting according to API version
- Changes to unit tests to deal with version specific status codes

NOTE: Client side changes are not in this branch.
They should be implemented within bp/quantum-client-1.1.
NOTE-2: Fixing references to QuantumHTTPErrors in extensions framework

Change-Id: I56f50b5c59d73fd6f02905106f0c2a3c8341a741

commit_message:
Bootstrap 2!

Implements blueprint bootstrap-2.

Notable changes:

  * Uses new split-dropdown buttons. Fixes bug 920820 and fixes bug 918452.
  * Uses bootstrap dropdowns for all menus. No differing implementations now.
  * Reworks how css class attributes are consructed on actions to make them
    easier to works with and support default classes.

Change-Id: Ia25edb6d8ca8a2d1ef30e8f9a36331eff4c7ae86

Initial cut at removing unneeded dependencies.

Removed deps left-over from quantum-server
Also Added 501 exceptions to client package.

Change-Id: I4aa45090ce211d29ae97d398572817a68f690122
